had the privilege to watch this last October 12 and let me just say that i enjoyed it very much.Manuel Quezon was the original politician of the Philippines. he knew how to control the people and how to get what he wants. i do believe he ran as a government official to help the Filipino people and gain independence from the Americans, but once you get a taste of fame, money, and power, those intentions can be easily forgotten. this movie came at the right time as it shows similarities on how our current government looks like. we are in the hands of fickle-minded politicians who only care about themselves. it's upsetting how even 90 years later we are still in the same mess. i always envy how other countries have better transportation systems, better work opportunities, and just better everything just because they were served by people who want real change in their country. still, i would never stop dreaming for real change in our country, and i feel that this movie gives hope to its viewers. amazing performances from everyone in the cast, the message/story was clear, and can't wait to support more Filipino-made movies!!

Source: www.reeladvice.net/2025/10/quezon-2025-movie-review.htmlThe war is over, and now the battle is set in the world of politics. Quezon takes us front and center into the seemingly heroic life of Manuel L. Quezon - a personality Filipinos look up to as a hero, a visionary, and one of the nation‚Äôs key founders. But much like its predecessors in the Bayaniverse franchise, the film tackles head-on the sheer humanity and fallibility of Quezon, questioning whether the ends justify the means in the battlefield of power and the making of a young nation.Manuel L. Quezon (Jericho Rosales) has just won the 1935 elections, becoming the first elected Filipino president and the second president of the Philippines. But the journey to win that coveted and historically significant seat wasn‚Äôt an easy one, and you don‚Äôt get to the top without getting your hands dirty and making a few enemies along the way.On its third outing, the Bayaniverse comes full circle by slowly shifting from the action-packed Heneral Luna to a somber drama in Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral and finally to a full blown political drama in Quezon. The literal battles here are replaced by heated confrontations between Quezon and his contemporaries, showing how he fought and negotiated his way through power by any means necessary. While we can‚Äôt say for sure if every revelation in the film is historically accurate, this is far from the textbook version of Quezon we grew up with. This is a human Manuel Quezon up front and center. One who is charming, cunning, and deeply flawed. The film hits hard, especially when viewed against the backdrop of today‚Äôs political landscape, reminding us that the people we idolize are often far more complicated than their public images suggests.The film‚Äôs chapter-based narrative structure was something we appreciated, breaking down Quezon‚Äôs political battles into distinct segments. However, the pacing felt uneven at times, with one chapter taking up a disproportionate part of the runtime. In terms of performances, though, everyone delivered. Mon Confiado stood out as a somber, grounded Emilio Aguinaldo, while Jericho Rosales embodied Quezon‚Äôs ambition and deceitful charm perfectly. We found ourselves surprisingly invested in Quezon, and by the time the credits rolled, it hit us hard much like the other Bayaniverse films. Like before, it left questioning whether the struggles we face today were shaped by the same heroes we‚Äôve long revered. As a potential bookend to the franchise, Quezon closes the trilogy in the way we hoped it would which is powerful, reflective, and important for Filipinos.

I think it's really best to now see all three films as one long project, all of it built around the deconstruction of the national hero. It is through that lens that the character of Joven finally makes sense, the trilogy's audience surrogate who attaches himself to these larger-than-life figures, only to witness their downfall. Joven believes in the Great Man: in the singular figures that will lead our nation out of the darkness. The film openly exposes that idea as foolhardy at best, because these Great Men are just people, too. And they're all deeply flawed individuals that just get their dirty laundry swept under the bed precisely because they feel like they could be our saviors.This third film is practically a farce, with Rosales' Manuel L. Quezon treating nationhood as a rigged game where only he can come out on top. He blatantly lies to his friends when it's convenient to do so, and accumulates power through every dirty trick in the politician's playbook. He is the Ur-TRAPO, basically creating the systems that would make TRAPOs an inescapable reality in the Philippines.Rosales is terrific here, his Quezon constantly performing for whoever's in front of him. He projects being a loyal ally, or a mentor, or a friend, or indeed the great savior of the Philippines. He plays that big, while in private moments Quezon is all vulnerability: a man who sees how delicate the house of cards he's built is, and worries about whether his health will allow him to see his dreams come to fruition.I do think the film has a tendency to overexplain, to have characters speaking the subtext out loud. But considering how some people took Heneral Luna, maybe this was always the tack to take. In any case, the film is unequivocal with how it wants us to see Quezon: he is what Chiz Escudero wants to be, and maybe what made Chiz Escudero possible. Welcome to our Sad Republic. Here's the guy that made it happen.

One McGuffin in the film is a Philippine peso coin that Quezon offers Joven the first time they meet. Quezon tells Joven, ‚Äúpasisikatin ko ang pangalan mo,‚Äù ‚ÄúI will make your name famous.‚Äù It is offered as a symbol of promise. Later in the film, we understand that Quezon is a businessman and how we sees his wits as he steers money into his electoral campaign. Quezon knows how to invest in the hearts of the people he influences. He fully understands the weakness of Filipinos when it comes to ‚Äúutang na loob‚Äù or debt of gratitude. We see this coin move between Quezon and Joven. Joven, who later finds out Quezon‚Äôs dirty tricks, returns the coin. In the last act, the coin is returned, becoming a powerful metaphor for the cost Filipinos pay when voting for leaders who manipulate their perception.Quezon is intriguing, comical at times, but otherwise compelling in that you‚Äôre hypnotized and drawn to the flipping of Quezon‚Äôs coin, who is on one side a hero, and on the other a flawed human being. We see him as a player, incisive in his chess pieces in Philippine politics. But also a sociopath when he deals with his cards in a game of poker with his enemies. The dialogue in the film never lets up, with pacing that keeps you glued to your seat. The film makes you love-hate the man, and Jericho Rosales‚Äô performance stands out, supported by an impressive powerhouse cast.Overall, the film is witty and entertaining. The political play may be on the nose, but should not alienate a regular Filipino moviegoer. And should be able to provide a proper dissection of the politicians we placed in their positions, and a wake-up call to vote better in the next elections.see video version on Tiktok or Instagram @reyraymundv

The Bayaniverse films have always been about showing how these heroes, whom we have put up on a pedestal, are in reality very flawed humans as well. With ‚ÄòQuezon‚Äô we not only see a very flawed human, but one that could have possibly set up the many political systems in play today. Jericho Rosales who plays the titular chameleon ‚ÄòQuezon‚Äô brings his A game to the role. You can see his range with Quezon‚Äôs cunning smiles, and explosive anger. The entire cast is a powerhouse one as well, bringing their own strengths to their characters. Technically, I was impressed by how the film was shot, employing black and white film work to mimic films from the 1930s. The production design was also on point with the props and costumes used, even the set pieces were impressive. The story itself shows how Quezon, who might be seen as a hero, has some skeletons in his own closet, and even had some strings pulled to help his rise to power, the reveal is a treat, and even though this is already history, there was a scene where I had to hold my breath.

I had the privilege of watching ‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù last Sunday.The film in some way, gave me closure about what our politics are today‚Äîthough not the good kind of closure.I remember during the last elections, one of my professors was kind enough to ask the whole class how we were holding up. Of course, we felt cheated, beaten. When I returned the question to him, he sighed and said, ‚ÄúWell, sanay na kami.‚ÄùWatching Quezon, that statement makes even more sense. The film is a mirror‚Äîalmost like a satire‚Äîprotesting to our faces what we‚Äôve been enduring for years.We‚Äôre all familiar with the Filipino game of politics (brought to life first by our colonizers, if I may add), but seeing it up close through this film is heartbreaking.We are being played by our politicians, and though we feel it deeply today, it‚Äôs something that has persisted for years. In this case, even in our very early days of democracy.‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù premieres today in over 260 cinemas nationwide.

Jericho Rosales was an inspired choice to play the charismatic president, who spoke, argued and cursed with oratorical flair and passion. This film was certainly not romanticized nor haigographic. Rosales played him as domineering, devious, dishonest -- promoting a political culture so toxic that still pervades our government even almost century hence. Rosales's Quezon was fiercely egotistical up to his ultimate declaration of "I am the Philippines!" before the final fade to black.Full review: said-fred.blogspot.com/2025/10/review-of-quezon-commonwealth-chameleon.html

A pretty compelling dissection of the messiness of politics. Mind you there's some bits here I would have loved to have seen pared down-- some speeches here often read as plain and didactic as thesis statements and some visuals come across as painfully obvious. There's a lot of reiteration of the theme of games being played here in the pull for power, even down to, in one scene, a clear chessboard referenced in both dialogue and image in a moment of Quezon's play for power and assembly of political pieces. And to be honest, the whole idea of politics being a game is something that simply comes across as trite (I mean, there is already a biopic out there that exists called Quezon's Game).At the same time, you have to admire the ambition of just implementing those ideas so clearly on levels of craft and storytelling. On the whole this is a sumptuously put together film that manages to make a whole lot of talking deeply delightful. This is especially remarkable considering that A. Dialogue-heavy films can easily bore if pulled off improperly and B. Quezon as a person is a character that, in actuality, should come across as deeply uncompelling due to how awful he actually is as a person-- which the film does not shy away from. To tackle the former, some truly astounding filmmaking is on full display here, really playfully swinging that camera and injecting a constant sense of energy through the movement of visuals. And for the latter, this is simply a sharp, wise, and surprisingly comedic script that really sells in its details. Manuel Quezon ultimately is a mess of a human being, but the film really has a lot of fun examining how this man claimed power instead of resigning to singing praises on who this powerful person is. It becomes truly engaging, even clever as a film that dissects a man who is gifted and unmatched at negotiation and talking but ultimately is still acknowledged as deeply problematic. Other than that, the performances here really do a lot of heavy-lifting as well. Rosales makes a full meal of the material, really exuding effortless and entertaining charm. Confiado controls the screen whenever he appears. Ultimately, this is simply a delight to watch through and through. Which is pretty astounding for a film that is essentially just about a bunch of politicians bickering. Hey, tale as old as time.

Quezon (Jerrold Tarog, 2025) culminates the Bayani Trilogy that started with Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral. The trilogy examines three historical (and controversial) figures who helped in fleshing out our concept of a nation under tyrannical colonial rule. In this film, Manuel L. Quezon comes alive as a fierce politician who would stop at nothing to fulfill his ambition which is not to serve but to lead. He destroyed reputations and livelihoods of opponents and critics and possible nurtured the budding seeds of patronage politics which is still practiced contemporaneously. He loved the limelight (at some point, even literally), thrived in public attention, and treated the people in his circle depending on how useful they would be for his advancement. Public service is immaterial as long as benefits come pouring in.Jericho Rosales played Quezon with such aplomb and vigor that you couldn't help but be irritated at his antics. He is good. I had initial reservations when he was cast but I realized he was a good fit and he played the role well. He owns the screen every time he is on which could be reminiscent of how the real Quezon chews the scenery whenever he could. The film is a good reminder of how devious politicians could be and how easily can we be blinded by adoration even if we should have known better. If anything, this film posits that politicians come and go but our country remains and therefore, our faith should be placed on people who would serve it the best. Rating: 4/5
I LOVE IT

The finale (or is it?) to Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs ongoing thesis on what it means to be a national hero cleverly frames the retelling of the titular character‚Äôs life as a film within a film, one that‚Äôs purposefully laden with creative license and narrative freedom ‚Äî blending truth and fiction to get its themes across (or, depending on your politics, to serve as propaganda or a fluff piece). It‚Äôs fitting, then, that the final confrontation between the real-life character and the fictional surrogate who‚Äôs been our audience stand-in since the start of this interconnected project takes place inside a movie theater ‚Äî the very medium through which myths are made.The film ‚Äî and its film-within-the-film (yes, it gets that meta) ‚Äî traces Quezon‚Äôs journey from his beginnings as part of the revolutionary army, to his days as a lawyer of the people, to his rise from local town governor to the first president of an autonomous Philippine government, free from direct foreign control. Each retelling presents not so much the man himself, but how he wanted to be remembered: as a patriot, a reformist, a visionary ‚Äî or perhaps just a man intoxicated by the idea of power.We see a Quezon who thirsts not only for independence but also for control ‚Äî and at times, for affairs and questionable advances ‚Äî justifying the bending of truths and the moral grayness of politics as necessary evils to ‚Äúeffect real change.‚Äù He preaches independence to a populace not yet aware of what it truly means, wielding the idea as a political tool. Even when confronted by findings that autonomy may have come too soon ‚Äî that corruption and cronyism were inevitable ‚Äî he presses on, clinging to power in the name of progress.The production design is remarkable, a clear step up in scale and ambition ‚Äî grand, intricate, and indicative of a much higher budget. Tarog‚Äôs decision to divide the film into cinematic ‚Äúchapters‚Äù gives it an epic sweep, though it also makes the storytelling feel jumpy at times, leaving certain emotional and narrative threads unresolved. The script leans a bit too heavily on exposition, and the occasional bursts of humor sometimes undercut the otherwise serious tone.Still, Quezon (2025) succeeds where it matters most: in driving home its central theme ‚Äî that our so-called national heroes, for all their grandeur and idealism, were also deeply flawed, morally ambiguous men shaped by ambition and compromise. It leaves us with a haunting question that lingers long after the credits roll:Are our political leaders ‚Äî past and present ‚Äî truly heroes, or simply the kind of villains we‚Äôve learned to celebrate?
Script was too preachy, didactic, and Araling Panlipunan coded. Gwapo ni Jericho.

Quezon closes the Bayaniverse trilogy with a dark third act leaving the viewers to ponder the lessons of history and how the game of politics is being played, realizing that the pursuit of power can corrupt and victimizes everyone. The mini Quezon campaign movie was a stroke of genius, and becomes a distinct factor deviating from the first two films (Luna and Goyo). Jericho Rosales, Mon Confiado, Iain Glen and the whole cast deliver remarkable performances. Congrats to TBA studios and director Jerrold Tarrog for concluding this trilogy.

I'm still not convinced that we need a film about Quezon because he is so bland as a greedy populist political figure that any attempt to explore him will be preachy and on-the-nose, relentlessly hammering the problem with the current zeitgeist with little catharsis. It entailed a perilous narrow line between portraying him as a brilliant charismatic political mastermind or a typical power hungry politician who reflect most public servant in the government today that they framed this story with journalists and filmmakers who would provide the commentary for the audience. It was looking at the eponymous protagonist from a distance, dissecting his essence and stripping him of all subjectivity, but it was also not presented objectively since they needed to ensure that the audience would not receive the wrong message, so more telegraphed commentary from the minor character. They should have simply written an informative paper discussion instead of making a film about the subject, because they had a lot to say but no compelling story to tell. It was so disorganized narratively that halfway through the film, it was difficult to tell where it was meant to go, and at least three elderly audience members were sleeping and snoring loudly from my theater.The visual language utilized in this movie is quite odd, most likely because they are unable to find a mean to convey the screenplay in a cinematic or visually appealing manner. It kept repeating the same shots and camera movements, which grew tedious at some point given the scale and time period it meant to communicate. There are too many tilt and boom shots, and the blocking tends to follow a formalism with a lot of symmetrical orientation that looked so theatrical with the camera slowly moving in, even though they desperately needed dynamic filmmaking to hide the limited production design. It relied on theatricality to pull this off, and even the performances adapt that theatrical mechanics where it devolved into actors yelling their dialogue, which was noticeable with the pitch of the sound, prompting me to be conscious with the sound system to see whether the problem was with the theater or the sound mixing itself. Not to nitpick the technical filmmaking further, but the way they filmed those propaganda short films looked too modern for the time period, and not because they were shot with a digital camera, which is totally understandable for budgetary purposes and accessibility of equipment, but they were edited and lit with a modern sensibility. Nonetheless, the intent of those short films narratively was rather intriguing since I'm pretty sure they were fictional and only used as a narrative device for the commentary. It was trying to offer that film within a film structure, peeling away the propaganda, but it just became too on-the-nose and a convenient excuse for their chosen narrative structure. They should have adopted a traditional narrative approach for this film since it would have been more compelling to show that point-of-view as Quezon rose and fell, with all of his hypocrisy and politicking, but doing so could have humanized the protagonist to the point that the audience would love him. It was a tricky film to make, and I appreciate that it did not humanize or glorify Quezon as an anti-hero at all, but it grew monotonous and painfully obvious when it could have been more mean-spirited and nuanced. I am so familiar with Quezon's political career that I was able to follow all of the political strife in the film, which made me upset since it seemed like I was reading my notes from my history class rather than following a cohesive narrative. However, I'm not sure what an audience unfamiliar with the subject matter can take away from this film, which moves from one battle after another with far too many expositions. It was bombastic and loaded with information, and without knowing the significance and relationship of each character, along with the political backdrop around the time, it will probably be alienating for others. It was still able to deliver some of the story in an innovative way, notably the Quezon versus Osmena fight, which is the most visually interesting, easy-to-follow and entertaining story throughout the film. It is actually impressive how it created a pace and tone that made sense for what it was trying to do narratively.Lastly, I want to discuss the Aguinaldo aspect, which was jarring since it nearly made him likable and probably the protagonist of this film, despite having a far worse reputation than most national heroes. It further claims that Quezon invented the beliefs that Aguinaldo killed Luna. It was strange since the film rehabilitated him with a title credit that celebrated how he is the last one to die among Quezon, Osmena and Roxas. Are we expected to feel bad for him? I don't know about that, and the way it was dramatized at the end makes it seem like we were wrong to hate him all along. Aside from being a nepo baby, I believe he tried to sold the Philippines revolution to the Spaniards in exchange for an exile in Hong Kong and allegedly 800,000 that is supposed to be handed in two parts, one of which were delivered but the other half was not, so he resumed the revolution. It almost feels like it was gaslighting the audience, but it was more likely illustrating that Quezon is beloved when he is actually worse.**Endnote: How dare them not to mention Pascual Racuyal, the bulakenyo mechanic who run for presidency every election from 1935 until the snap election during 1986?

the thing about this franchise is its not afraid to use the facts of yesterday to comment of the reality of today. jerrold tarog finishes his 10 year stint in this historical trilogy with quezon. far from the battlefields that defined heneral luna and goyo comes the new front of politics, and its a fight that manuel luis quezon knows how to win, for better or for worse. the film shines in its synthesis of what made the previous films great: a showcase of personalities of the past that feel oddly familiar to modern audiences. quezon nudges the viewer to listen, to question, and most of all to look past the narratives sold to us and strive for the truth beneath it.have more thoughts, but it'll be spoiler territory, and i want to get the book before commenting on the historical parts! good watch, and i want to catch this again in cinemas.

‚Äúindependence is good enough to eat‚Äùtime and time again, it is almost the destiny of filipinos to be deluded by elaborate images rather than genuine performances, believing in sugarcoated hollow promises, and in what the people in power want us to believe. however, we cannot deny that to an extent, filipinos are complicit to this cycle. we make the bed on which we lie. so much to ponder kung what if nalagay sa mabuting kamay ang pamamahala sa pilipinas from the very beginning pa lang. what if an established system of education and an understanding that these great men also had mud beneath their medals, taught our ancestors that independence was not good enough to eat? anyway, great score and cinematography as expected from a tba studios film. also, claps for jericho üëèüèº sad to see that the bayaniverse is ending‚Ä¶.. looking forward to more period pieces soon ü§ì paalala na huwag magpaloko at bumoto ng tama!

This movie really shows the dirty game of politics in the Philippines, and I love how it tells both sides of the story. It gives such a great perspective on how our government has always been a game of power, control, and manipulation. In the end, my biggest takeaway is this question: Was Quezon a hero or not? I‚Äôll leave that for you to figure out once you watch it.

First Time Watcher! I have not watched any other films in the bayaniverse trilogy and this was my first. Safe to say I may look into them because I LOVED THIS! Everything works together so well ‚Äî from the casting, music choices, filming perspectives, editing style, characters, and writing. Everyone who worked in this you deserve every piece of credit ü§çNot only does this depict how despicable Quezon was as a politician but even applies to the current state of Philippine politics and how politicians work to gain power. A friend who has watched the films in the bayaniverse told me this was a more ‚Äúlight‚Äù film compared to the other ones already released and that depicts a lot from Quezon‚Äôs character, a charismatic leader. I really enjoyed the campaign video having Quezon‚Äôs achievements and the alternative one showcasing the steps he took and people he conflicted with to be the man he is. And Jericho Rosales as Quezon? It works so well! The casting they do is so great and loved it a lot. Though I wish they didn‚Äôt picture Aguinaldo in a pitiful aspect since he has his fair share of dirt. Overall, a great cinematic masterpiece because I could apply my knowledge of politics and governance üò≠ü§ç Quezon may have had his lies and manipulation tactics, but he was right about how beautiful the film industry will be and still is. This film is solid proof to it. Great job to the people who worked on this!! Your art is loved!

‚ÄúI would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans, because however a bad Filipino government might be, we can always change it.‚Äù -Manuel L. Quezon, 1939Well we did it Quezon, we're now living in a country run like hell by Filipinos, like you said. Not sure how that last part of the quote will fare out, but let's hope it'll ring true at some point. Quezon is yet again another substantive display of one of the Philippine's most important historical figures. Following Heneral Luna and Goyo, this is Jerrold Tarog's third attempt of this kind of historical drama that puts these historical figures on the spotlight in a way that provides discourse on the political state of the Philippines during their time; a discourse of which that's unfortunately relevant to this day. As opposed to both Antonio Luna and Gregorio Del Pilar, who were generals, this film focuses on Manuel L. Quezon, a prominent Filipino political figure in the early 20th century (the 2nd Philippine President, specifically). While he's more known in the history books (or at least how I was taught in school) as someone who made changes in the Philippine government to make the nation more independent, the movie gives a transparent perspective of his rise to Presidency in both a positive light and negative light, the latter of which is shown in the misdeeds and manipulation he did behind the scenes in order to gain his power. It's come to the point where the interactions feel so Mean Girls-coded, in a sense where Filipino political affairs feel so parallel to high-school drama, where people try to one-up themselves over others in the political game of seeing whoever takes the highest form of power. It's funny to think about at first, but it's much more depressing if you really put your mind to it; Filipino politicians have never really gotten past this political game for power that it's still very much relevant to this day. Instead of addressing the actual issues in the country like the lack of education, proper infrastructure, and better living conditions for the lower class, you see Quezon do a lot of back-and-forth between his opponents and other people just to retain his position. And when he does interact with the lower class, he instills this fake hope in the independence of the Filipino nation, which sounds so good that even those who don't know what the word "independence" actually means were sold by his charismatic and inspiring words. Though Quezon has done a lot of good for the country, the film shows just how flawed he is, and how we shouldn't just take the positive impact he had, but also take in his wrongdoings as a view on the saddening reality of politics. There's a recurring motif of characters being tired of all the back-and-forth interactions that lead to nothing productive, which feels very reflective of how the director Jerrold Tarog feels about modern Filipino politics; he's tired of his more subtle approach in his two aforementioned films that he tackles the topic in this film in a more straightforward way.As a result, the film can get preachy and waaaaay too obvious in its approach to this topic, which throws subtlety out of the way. But I understand how this is done intentionally to really get the point across, especially to the young Filipino viewers who will be watching this and be urged by educators in doing so, especially through the student discounts (of which I got, because I'm still in college lol). Normally, I'd be against this obvious approach in such an important topic, but seeing that it intends on educating the Filipino youth regarding the political state of the country, and seeing how poor the reading and art comprehension are of most Filipinos, I can forgive the film for this. It has a lot of good things to say, albeit there were some inaccuracies here and there, though they were done for a more cohesive narrative and theme throughout. Jericho Rosales gave a really good performance as the titular character, Iain Glenn was a standout to me, despite his considerably short appearance, and there weren't any bad actors in this at all. Tarog's direction was quite good, the pacing was always on point and never got boring, the cinematography was mostly great, and the production and set design were so insanely well done and there was a lot of attention to detail. Though the editing can sometimes be jarring and the music gets a bit overbearing at times, the film was still really good overall. Really hope that the students watching this film will take the good out of the film and be inspired to become the change that we need in the Philippines, especially since the future isn't looking so bright for our country. I liked Lav Diaz's Magellan, but honestly I wish this were picked as the entry to the Oscars for Best Foreign Film instead. This was a much more accessible film that will definitely speak to a lot of Filipinos and will definitely leave a lasting impact to Filipinos much more than Magellan did. Not saying that the entry should be chosen based on accessibility, but rather, it should be chosen based on how important it is in representing the country's cinema as a whole, and this was a great representation for our country's cinema and our history. Sorry Lav Diaz, still love you tho king. üòôü´∂Films in 2025My ranking of Tarog's trilogy:Heneral Luna > Quezon > Goyo

A sharp, smart, and playful deconstruction of The Life of a Showman.It's all for show. A call for Independence. A promising election campaign. A mythmaking agenda built on propaganda. That's the thing about politicians‚Äîthey act, project, and perform for everyone. QUEZON is a timely & grim reminder that virtually nothing has changed over the last 100 years in our padrino & utang na loob ecosystem. In between political breakups and unnecessary theatrics, the country remains a farce governed by clowns. The film nudges the audience to see through the web of lies.What QUEZON also achieves brilliantly is turning political maneuverings into a compelling drama through a kinetic screenplay, smoothly switching from a frame story, to an analepsis, to its current timeline. Think Succession, but set in Malaca√±ang.The newspaper montage works as an effective storytelling device, grounding its viewers to the historical context. It tends to overexplain and simplify its message but in an age where satire is a dying art, this may be the way to make its point crystal clear. The dynamic blocking, characters walking ahead or standing a tier higher, are used to convey fragile egos, shifting alliances, and subtle power plays.Jericho Rosales is simply terrific, inhabiting the role with such bold, infectious energy. Jerrold Tarog skillfully balances tone and themes, providing a fresh way to tackle a historical drama. The ensemble is stellar across the board, with everyone getting their moment. Karylle, with limited screentime, leaves a lasting impression. She‚Äôs often seated while Quezon towers above, until a full-circle moment where life throws a reminder that power, like fate and politics, always turns like a wheel.Entertaining & thought-provoking, QUEZON is a fitting conclusion to the Bayaniverse trilogy. Brush up with your high school history knowledge to achieve a richer experience. TBA Studios should be proud of this, especially with its grand production that‚Äôs 100% deserving of the big screen. See it to believe it.

A scathing take down of the first president of the Commonwealth. Quezon is tagged as the pioneer of explicit patronage politics and the spoils of victory system where donors of the winning candidate get special deals and treatment as utang na loob. He did not invent the game but he normalized it from the highest position. This system hasn‚Äôt left us since, and has left us poor.From the victories of the power-hungry Quezon, of the power-hungry PLUS malevolent Marcos and Duterte families, our republic has a habit of losing.We keep falling for would be saviors‚Äîthose that promise independence, a golden era, or crime-free streets.The film puts journalism on a pedestal but also admits how it can fall prey to misdirection, disinformation, planted stories. There‚Äôs a scene that depicts creepy trolls confronting Aguinaldo, a la Duterte propaganda networks poisoning our information ecosystem, trying to scare opponents and opposing opinions.‚ÄúBeware of people who say they‚Äôll fight for you.‚Äú

ABSOLUTELY JARRING. ESPECIALLY THOSE LAST MINUTES!The entire experience felt like the entire movie that I watched was the Body & Soul concept that Joven Hernando kept bringing up several times in the movie. That duality is basically the whole point of Quezon's legacy.The narrative frames the entire viewing experience to feel as if we are watching Quezon's campaign unfold live. It‚Äôs wild because you know you‚Äôre supposed to be enticed by his noble lies, even while you can see the calculating political games happening behind all that famous charisma.And that's exactly why I love how this is so out of the box with how it was directed. Seriously, the structural choices are amazing.The first part is all shine and facade, there to show us the kind of politics Quezon wants us to see: the grand, heroic statesman fighting for independence.But the second part? That was everything that gave me goosebumps all throughout the second half of the film! It delivers the film‚Äôs devastating thesis by explicitly showing us the dirty politic framework Quezon has basically founded in this country, which we suffer to experience to this day.That face-off of Quezon and Aguinaldo? The acting of Jericho Rosales and Mon Confiado absolutely sealed my rating on this film. I can't believe a single "don't you dare" line could make me feel so tense!A must-watch if you want to understand why our system is the way it is now. And with the film's tagline as "The Last Quest to Define Bayani"? Well, it might not be as heroic as we all thought it is.

It's funny how this movie, even with all its fictional creative freedom, perfectly mirrors the political realities of the Philippines today. Jerrold Tarog doesn't just present a history lesson, he offers a raw, unflinching look at the budding Philippine government in a way that contemporary audiences should study closely. The film makes it brutally clear that this country's foundation wasn't laid purely with high ideals and patriotism, but was instead built on a messy combination of greed, manipulation, betrayal, and the relentless pursuit of power.What truly stings was the realization that after decades upon decades of supposed journey toward claiming true independence and stability, we always seem to cycle back to the same messy politics, just in a different font and under new names. And at the center of this perpetually recurring drama, the film powerfully argues, is a key player silently pulling the strings, moving the local pawns for their own geopolitical gain: the Americans. The film's narrative highlights how foreign interests often shaped the domestic landscape, making us question who are our true allies and enemies.This is uncomfortably sad, but Quezon is beyond a mere entertainment affair. It‚Äôs not just a historical drama but rather an outcry of what we have become as a nation, especially how we form our opinions with blind idolatry in mind, just like how Quezon blindly idolizes himself of what he thought he was, and that in itself is alarming.

Structured differently from the first two films. There are no flashy battles to be found but a reflection of Quezon‚Äôs political career, the choices he made, his mistakes, and his flaws. It shows a president widely believed to be a hero as a deeply flawed man who made many contributions to the country but also contributed and perpetuated many of the issues plaguing the current political system in the country.

The most riveting deconstruction of a ‚ÄúBayani‚Äù in the trilogy.Narcissism, self-interest, power, and charisma: these traits expose a corrupt personality (sounds familiar, diba?). Yet collectively, most (if not all) Filipinos remain blinded every election season.It‚Äôs sad how the dramatization of these historical events were never far from the reality we live in today. Quezon‚Äôs influence on the kind of government we have now are all things hilarious, admirable, and harrowing.One of the nation‚Äôs most entertaining wake-up calls ever.I am the Philippines.

Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs Quezon asks: what if nation-building was just really good stage direction? Gone are the bullets of Heneral Luna and the heartbreak of Goyo‚Äîhere, the fiercest battles happen behind podiums and in front of cameras.Every handshake feels like a chess move, every line delivery a soft coup. I was genuinely fascinated by the sheer calculated brilliance of this version of Quezon‚Äîconniving, persuasive, and dangerously aware of his own myth. He doesn‚Äôt chase power; he curates it.I came expecting a history lesson.I stayed for the masterclass in manipulation.And I left wondering if Quezon‚Äôs real genius was knowing that legacy, like film, only needs the right edit.

‚ÄúMasyadong maraming politiko sa bansa. Kaunti lang ang lingkod bayan‚ÄùI wish we all had a lens clear enough to see what truly drives every politician when they chase power.Watching how Quezon played with the emotions of those around him, with position and power, I couldn‚Äôt help but wonder: maybe deception has long been ingrained in what it means to be Filipino. Maybe we‚Äôve always been ‚Äúmabilis mabilog‚Äù and ‚Äúmagaling mambilog‚Äù. This is where the cycle started, and no doubt why it still continues. It‚Äôs a system like a game with set mechanics‚Äîonly the players change, and the tricks evolve.The film itself is incredible. There‚Äôs a sense of power here that‚Äôs difficult to explain and an emotional pull so strong you can‚Äôt decide whose side you‚Äôre on, because each character‚Äôs truth unfolds with raw honesty. You see their flaws, their desires, and how their ideals clash for the same country. Oh and i love how Tarog uses cinema and journalism as tools of truth. The transitions, the way history is woven through reels of film, are brilliant. The color palette alone tells a story‚ÄîQuezon bathed in rich, vivid hues, while Aguinaldo fades into muted tones. And the score! Haha. The circus-like and chaotic score is perfect reflection of the madness, the spectacle that politics has always been. Ang husay. The cast is insane, and I couldn‚Äôt be more proud because wow..such a powerful ensemble of artists.Jerrold Tarog is bold and fearless, and such a great storyteller.By the end of the film, I found myself asking: Will this game ever end? Americans. Filipinos.. I hope one day, the mechanics will change. One day, may the rules will finally be rewritten.At para sa mga trapo sa henerasyong ‚Äòto, nakita na namin ang mga laro ninyo..‚ÄúHINDI KAMI KULANGOT, HUWAG N‚ÄôYO KAMING BILUGIN!‚Äù

As the Bayaniverse comes to a close, we now see Joven Hernando for who he's always been: all of us. The quintessential Filipino everyman; blissfully hopeful yet willfully ignorant when it suits him. Someone so desperate for salvation they kneel before madmen, canonizing them as saints. And when this precarious house of cards that they‚Äîwe‚Äîhave helped build comes tumbling down, blame spreads like thick, choking smoke and we're left exposed, haunted by our own folly and the delusions we built our faith upon. Like the return of a Marcos to power, propped up by the despotic Duterte machinery, and the mess that ensued. But not all comebacks have to be so daunting. Take Jericho Rosales here for example, who plays MLQ with such clinical ostentation that it almost feels borderline icky. But. He's. Just. So. Spectacular. And. Looks. So. Damn. Good. To. Look. Away. From.

If you've been seated to all the recent Senate Hearings, you'll enjoy this one. How the blatant lying, constant blaming and power-grabbing are all just a huge circus show, and with Quezon as PT Barnum in the middle of it. This is a good way to end the Bayani Trilogy (or is it the end?) as the so called glorious acts of these people are finally scrutinized through the film narrative. Anyway, I've enjoyed myself entirely. I'm not sure about the audiences that I've watched this with. Not sure if they're just a tough crowd or like Joven, they're also bewildered to the fact that this is our reality, and an ongoing one . Either way, this film delivered brilliantly, and Jericho Rosales is absolutely perfect on this.

It‚Äôs a film within a film, at napaka-creative kasi angkop ito sa panahon at setting ng American colonial era sa Pilipinas. Tarog never disappoints. Di gaya‚Ä¶

Quezon by Jerrold Tarog#CJSays Super Nice! 4/5 stars ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Finally after years of waiting, the third installment to the Bayaniverse is here! I'm so excited to watch this since I'm so curious to get to know President Quezon like what Direk Jerrold did to Heneral Luna and Goyo and after watching this movie twice, andami Kong naisip after.We all know that President Manuel L.Quezon is that guy from the 20 pesos bill and our "Ama ng Wikang Pambansa" but in this movie, they were able to humanize him, Nasabi ko sa sarili ko na, Gaya din sya ng iba! The ensemble cast were all brilliant! Kudos to the cast led by Jericho Rosales who really gave justice to the role! This is his best performance yet and I will not be surprised if he will get an award through this movie! His portrayal is powerful! Sir Mon Confiado is always on top of his game in everything he does, nabigyan ng character arc si Aguinaldo dito, I'm also happy that Joven was given a spotlight here and kudos to Sir Cris Villanueva and Arron Villaflor! Bagay Kay Karylle ang role na Aurora Quezon!The cinematography is good, the set design is perfect! It feels like I was transported to the Commonwealth era! The story focuses on the rise to power of Quezon but I wish they also featured his early life like his lovestory with Aurora, exciting story Sana yun since they were cousins (Yes!) and also I wish nabigyan din ng highlight si Dona Aurora since she's a vital character in Quezon's life and to the history of the Philippines, Quezon was told in a non linear storytelling and sometimes I got confused if the scene is a backstory, or a scene to Nadia's movie or a scene in the present time, may blur yun department na yun and how I wish it was polished!After watching the movie as I leave the cinemas, mapapaisip ka, bakit sa Kabila ng lahat, mula noon hanggang ngayon, why are we still electing trapo leaders? Para syang multo na hindi matakasan!Quezon is an important movie event best experience in cinemas, it mirrors the current state of our nation with the recent happenings nowadays (That Quezon vs Osmena for example) and I hope this movie ignites our awakening to choose and vote the right leaders! We should act now! Overall, Quezon is a good swan song to the Bayaniverse! Don't leave the cinemas during the credit rolls or you'll miss SOMETHING! Is it an end of an era or a start of a new revolution?

But now, it feels like a prophecy. A mirror held up to the nation we‚Äôve become. Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs final installment in the Bayaniverse trilogy‚ÄîQuezon‚Äîcarried with it a weight of expectation. Just as Luna and Goyo startled a curious‚Ä¶

It blends humor, satire, truth, and explicitness! The cinematography is superb, and I like how unique it is compared to other local films across genres‚Äîespecially how distinct it feels from Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs Bayaniverse. And like many other political films in the Philippines, it doesn‚Äôt necessarily offer something new, but it gave me a fresh perspective on the downside of hero worship‚Äîhow we often forget that the heroes we idolize are still human, flawed, and capable of mistakes.‚ÄúHindi nakalaya ang mga Pilipino, hindi nakalaya ang ating bayan. At ang malupit na katotohanan: sa pagkakataong ito, wala nang bansang kailangang manakop upang ipagkait sa atin ang kalayaan‚Äîsapagkat tayong mga Pilipino mismo ang hindi marunong lumaya. Sa sarili nating paninikil, ganid, ang kulturang utang na loob at katapatan sa maling damo, at sa paulit-ulit na pagpili sa sarili kaysa sa bayan. Ilang henerasyon na nating binibihag ang ating mga sarili, ilang Quezon pa ba ang darating upang humingi ng independencia at gaya niya ay paulit-ulit na maligaw ng landas. Sapagkat sa bawat panahon, may Quezon sa ating lahat‚Äîang hunyangong handang isuko ang katotohanan, basta‚Äôt manatiling nasa trono ng ilusyon.‚Äù (Excerpt from my reflection essay on [Quezon])

It‚Äôs always a peculiar experience watching a Jerrold Tarog film. There‚Äôs a quiet unease that comes with it. Maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve followed his work long enough to know he never really plays it safe; every film feels like a balancing act between vision and vulnerability. I know he‚Äôs not flawless, and neither are his films, even the ones I hold close (Confessional, Senior Year, Bliss). But there‚Äôs something about the way he tells stories that always feels searching and alive. He‚Äôs never been after polish (and sometimes that‚Äôs the most frustrating part of his cinema) but he‚Äôs always been after answers. New answers to the kind of questions only a history geek would ask in the shower. So whenever I enter a Direk Jerrold film, I brace, because I know it might reveal something I wasn‚Äôt ready to see about us, or about what we‚Äôve become.Of all the BAYANIVerse films, QUEZON feels the most adventurous ‚Äî not in scale, but in spirit. It‚Äôs Direk Jerrold‚Äôs boldest experiment in this saga: a film that knows it‚Äôs a film. He borrows from Mike de Le√≥n‚Äôs Bayaning Third World, playing with the grammar of cinema itself: reenactments, reconstructions, meta-frames. The satire is there, but softer now, as if Direk Jerrold has accepted that to film history is to fictionalize it. Every frame of patriotism is, by nature, a kind of performance.What‚Äôs interesting is how Quezon almost feels like a return to where Direk Jerrold began: to the heart of his first feature Confessional. That film was all about guilt and exposure. It blurred the line between truth and performance, between what‚Äôs real and what‚Äôs edited for the camera. Quezon carries that same unease, only now the canvas is larger: not one man‚Äôs confession, but an entire nation‚Äôs. It‚Äôs still about projection; about editing who we say we are. In both films, Direk Jerrold wrestles with the same dilemma: that the story of the country, like the story of the self, is always partly fabricated. The distance between public myth and private truth isn‚Äôt new to him; it‚Äôs the ground he‚Äôs been standing on all along.The beginning, though, is difficult. It unfolds like an essay: brisk, detached, almost indifferent to its own characters. We‚Äôre given on-screen identifiers to remember names, but no real reason to care about them yet. It‚Äôs matter-of-fact to the point of numbness. And while I understand the intention ‚Äî that deliberate coldness, that resistance to sentimentality ‚Äî it keeps me at a distance. Maybe that‚Äôs the point: that our first encounter with history is always sterile, a list of names before they become people. But it‚Äôs still a hard place to start for a film that ultimately depends on emotional investment. If the audience doesn‚Äôt feel invited in, the ideas risk floating above the story, detached from the very humanity they‚Äôre trying to illuminate. It‚Äôs a fascinating gamble: to alienate first, and hope empathy arrives later.Eventually, it warms. Theory turns into theater: infidelity, betrayal, the exhausting pettiness of ambition. The shift happens quietly, and suddenly, these figures in textbooks begin to ache, to resent, to want. The sarcasm becomes sorrow. Direk Jerrold lets Quezon‚Äôs charisma clash with his contradictions, and the film begins to reveal what the trilogy has been circling all along: that our heroes were never saints, just men rehearsing greatness for a stage called history.Still, Quezon is uneven in texture. It moves between stylization and realism so freely that the seams sometimes show. One moment it looks painterly, the next like something out of a morning kiddie show. Some transitions feel deliberate; others feel like accidents. At times I even caught myself wondering ‚Äî is this stylized, or a little off? But at some point, the film begins to carry those inconsistencies as part of its design. The tone itself becomes a kind of argument: that history, like cinema, is never seamless. Its rough edges start to feel less like errors and more like evidence: that the story of a nation is always told through competing frames, through sincerity and performance, myth and memory all bleeding into one another.It‚Äôs also the most intimate of the trilogy, and paradoxically, the smallest. The 1935 election feels less like a historical event and more like a town contest, the scale reduced to smoke-filled rooms, small plaza gatherings, and even smaller street marches. But maybe that‚Äôs where politics truly happens: not on the battlefield, but in the room where stories are shaped or in those short walks in between campaign speeches. The Philippines, Direk Jerrold seems to say, wasn‚Äôt born in fire but in fog ‚Äî not through heroism, but through negotiation. He shrinks the myth to scale, and somehow that feels truer.Jericho Rosales is remarkable. His Quezon is a performer to his bones: charming, strategic, aware that every gesture is part of a show. It‚Äôs a portrayal that understands leadership as theater. But it‚Äôs Karylle as Aurora Quezon and Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osme√±a who give the film its soul probably because I believe they are able to play characters that are also written better. They play the roles history often edits out ‚Äî the ones who absorb power‚Äôs aftershocks. Their warmth gives the film the emotional gravity that its cleverness sometimes withholds.And the film is funny! Not that it‚Äôs a surprise, since the trailers already gave that away. But what‚Äôs interesting is how the humor works; it never feels forced. In all the politics of it all, the humor really lands. You laugh, but it‚Äôs the kind of laughter that feels like recognition ‚Äî the ache of realizing how cyclical our myths have become. Watching Quezon today, it‚Äôs hard not to see the reflection: new leaders, same spectacle, the same applause for the illusion of change. The crowd has changed, but the choreography hasn‚Äôt. Politics has always been performance; we‚Äôve just upgraded the stage lights.[SPOILER ALERT]What makes Quezon linger though isn‚Äôt how it ends, but how it fades. In a quiet mid-credits scene, a radio hums with ‚ÄúMambo Magsaysay.‚Äù It sounds harmless at first, even nostalgic, until it sinks in. The trilogy that began with men dying for freedom ends with a jingle: a hero reborn not through valor, but through publicity. The revolution has learned rhythm; the myth, melody. What began in blood and fire now survives through broadcast. Heroism no longer dies; it loops endlessly on air, selling itself back to a nation that keeps forgetting.Maybe that‚Äôs Direk Jerrold‚Äôs quiet brilliance. Heneral Luna was about rage ‚Äî the passion that builds nations. Goyo was about disillusionment ‚Äî how conviction collapses once heroism becomes habit. Quezon is about myth ‚Äî how belief turns into image, and image into machinery. It‚Äôs not just the end of a trilogy; it‚Äôs the moment when the revolution becomes a system. Because Quezon, for all his brilliance, also built the architecture of the politics we still live in: the patronage, the alliances, the transactional warmth that makes power feel personal but never equal. The birth of democracy was also the birth of dependency.And if the hinted Magsaysay film ever comes, then it will tell the story of how that system learned to sing. Because Magsaysay was the first modern president sold like an idea ‚Äî a leader branded through music, charisma, and American approval. His legacy marks the shift from politics as negotiation to politics as emotion. If Luna died for the nation, and Quezon built it, then Magsaysay would show how the nation learned to perform itself ‚Äî how conviction turned into choreography, leadership into branding, and the state into a stage where power thrives not by being just, but by looking relatable.The question now isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúWho is the hero?‚Äù but ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs holding the camera ‚Äî and for which story, for whose gain, and at what cost to the truth?‚Äù

The long-awaited final chapter in the Bayaniverse trilogy brilliantly shifts gears from the battlefield to the backroom, immersing us in the ruthless political game that defined the early Philippine Commonwealth. If nothing else, it shows that 100 years ago marumi na ang pulitika sa Pilipinas. The story is eerily reminiscent of the current political landscape na kung sinabi mo sakin na last month lang sinulat at ginawa to, pwedeng maniwala ako.Director Jerrold Tarog, once again, doesn't offer a statue but a scalpel, dissecting the myth of Manuel L. Quezon. This film is a compelling, dialogue-driven epic that strips away the heroic luster to reveal the manipulative acumen, charm, and sheer ambition required to forge a nation. It‚Äôs a messy portrait that feels urgently relevant, proving that the high drama of power politics can be as engrossing as any war epic.For me, the performances elevate the entire experience. Jericho Rosales is genuinely great in the titular role; he captures the former President's fire and charisma while still managing to hint at the deep contradictions beneath the tailored suits. However, this is truly an ensemble piece, and Romnick Sarmenta (as Sergio Osme√±a) and Mon Confiado (reprising Aguinaldo) also shine, providing compelling foils and complexity. They make the political chess feel weighty and personal. Game of Thrones alum Iain Glen is a welcome and commanding presence, though I have to admit, his very distinct British accent occasionally pulls me out of the moment because he‚Äôs playing an American character - but maybe that‚Äôs just me being picky.I genuinely admire and respect the approach that Jerrold Tarog and team chose for this movie. A simpler but probably more boring version of this would be a straight up biopic that mythologizes Quezon. That being said, I sincerely hope our audiences are truly ready for a treatment of a national subject such as this, one that so meticulously deconstructs the idea of a great man. It requires a level of critical historical consumption that can sometimes be lacking. This film isn't just a history lesson; it's a call for discernment, and I hope Pinoys are able to understand and grapple with the deeper message it provides.My worst fear, and what keeps me thinking about the film's potential impact, is for people to come out of this movie with a shallow understanding‚Äîwith the notion that all politicians are fundamentally flawed, so it's okay to support the corrupt ones they are currently "fans" of. I have this suspicion that when some people saw Heneral Luna, ang takeaway nila ay ‚ÄúKita mo na! Kaya okay lang yung matapang tsaka palamura e‚Äù rather than the bigger and more important lessons that the movie tried to impart about nationalism.Quezon shows complexity, not blanket moral equivalence. It shows a flawed man achieving monumental goals, but critically examines the cost. It is a brilliant and challenging piece of filmmaking with terrific performances from the cast. It should be watched, discussed, and debated for years to come.

I‚Äôve always loved antihero narratives, and Quezon fits that mold perfectly. The film illustrates how populism can bring one to power. It skirted on a single word, "independence", and forces you to ask what it has ever truly meant. After all, the government we have now is the same one we‚Äôve always had, merely dressed in different fashions for each generation.But where the film stumbles is in telling historical facts. Too much of its narrative hinges on the fictional character Joven Hernando and his descent into Quezon‚Äôs pitfall of populism and cronyism. This might have worked if Quezon were intended as historical fiction. But it's not. It focused too much on Joven‚Äôs disillusionment and Quezon‚Äôs perspective that it glossed over factual events a historical film should have covered.Overall, the film was both compelling and timely. I only hope we finally learn not to mistake charisma with integrity. Lies and manipulations, however noble the cause, are always self-serving. In a nation built on lies, speaking the truth is the greatest act of defiance. When will we ever learn? Only history can tell. But one thing is certain: every strongman, liar and fascist cult leader is destined for downfall.

Always a bad sign when a historical biopic feels more like a high school history lesson, and that's already with liberties taken creatively. It's also quite funny how Quezon took more than 2 hours to show how Filipino (and American?) elites have used senseless politicking and nationalist posturing in their selfish quest to acquire more political power, only to end up crediting landgrabbers and bureaucrat capitalists as its producers. End this Bayaniverse franchise now.

It's odd that a film so much about a man who campaigned on national independence, whose supposed saving grace is that he ultimately did bring it about, says so little about what that independence even meant. This film adds nothing to the discourse of national independence.This is another glossy entry to Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs ‚ÄúBayani-verse‚Äù series of films, which some have described as an attempt to deconstruct the Philippine national hero. It's the most fictionalized of the three*. And it's another one that gets worse the more you think about it. Hopefully it‚Äôs the last, as they say, for I have no interest in seeing another one of these movies about Ramon Magsaysay. My biggest issue with this film in particular is that it subsists so much on the surface of its subject matter that it fails to say anything interesting about the context in which its events occur. What does it actually say about the 50-year American occupation of the Philippines? What does it actually say about Manuel Quezon as a president? As a leader of the country? What does it say about how everyday Filipinos experienced his rule? Does it say anything at all?It's mostly about Manuel Quezon as a politician, or more so, how he performs politics. It's about his two-facedness, his scrupulousness, his constant need to one-up his political opponents at any chance he gets. The film successfully contextualizes the absurd spectacle of 21st century politics by telling us that its roots go back to the very inception of our political independence nearly a century ago. But this is also where the film's issues lie.The film appears to critique Quezon for how he participated in and fine-tuned the garish spectacle of modern political campaigning, of setting the stage for our present day election cycles. But despite the film‚Äôs acknowledgment of the shallowness of these tactics, it still chooses to disproportionately focus on them. It reduces the American occupation of the Philippines to a series of interpersonal squabbles, as opposed to focusing on the actual impact of Quezon‚Äôs rule over the Filipinos at the time. Based on what we see in the film, the legacy of Manuel Quezon is in how he engaged with politics, as opposed to the impact of his actions on everyday people. But what was the actual situation of Filipinos back then? One of the only times we hear the perspective of a farmer is to highlight their ignorance of the word ‚Äúindependence.‚Äù A few scenes later we hear Osme√±a and Quezon agree with Leonard Wood that the Filipinos just aren't ready for independence yet. But why? The film doesn't explore it further. And in the latter half of the film, some of the more intriguing critiques of Quezon‚Äôs political impact on the country are undermined by the fact that they‚Äôre coming out of the mouth of Emilio Aguinaldo, the Bayani-verse‚Äôs primary villain.There's just no inkling at all in the film of what life was like for the average Filipino under American occupation or the Quezon-led Commonwealth. It's 2025. We need to be looking past myopic personalizations of the past. We need to think about the actual situations of the Filipino people. We need to think about what independence actually means and what form of "independence" we actually got, both in 1935 and 1946. We don't need more Great Man biopics.Does the film have anything to say about independence at all? We hear the word constantly bandied around like a slogan, as if saying it out loud is enough to signal what the country needs. But the filmmakers don't bother to unpack it. Perhaps the real-life Quezon also didn't explain what was meant by this in the 1920s and 1930s, but that shouldn't excuse our filmmakers today. Unless they genuinely believe that all independence entails is a democracy to vote for our leaders. Perhaps a good question to ask is the opposite. How did Quezon continue the structures of colonial dominance during his rule?What the film seems to try to say is that our first president embodied a lot of the best and worst qualities of many politicians today, but ultimately, it can perhaps be justified because it was for something greater ‚Äî it was for our independence. But it doesn't bother to explore what this proposed independence even means; it doesn't bother to distinguish political and economic independence; it doesn't even offer any useful corollaries to thinking about these issues today.So why was this film even made?*What makes it so much more fictionalized than the previous two films is the huge prominence of the narrative conceit of telling the film through the perspectives of Joven Hernando and his daughter. The closing down of Hernando‚Äôs Alerta publication and the idea of a young female director shooting short films to publicize Quezon‚Äôs campaign are totally fictional. There was some suppression of the press, for sure, during Quezon‚Äôs time, but Alerta doesn‚Äôt have any direct correlates. Perhaps it‚Äôs more to symbolize the shut down of ABS-CBN during Rodrigo Duterte‚Äôs term. And I could be wrong, but I don‚Äôt think Quezon had films made about himself to promote his campaign. Ferdinand Marcos definitely did though. **Very briefly towards the end of the film we get a 30-second critique of Quezon's impact on patronage politics and the disbursement of spoils (pork barrel). That's good. But I don't think it makes up for the other 130 minutes or so of the film that takes more seriously as an issue scandals such as whether he had a first wife or not.

And that closes the Bayaniverse. With my favorite BL ng PH History.Ang intact padin ng messaging hanggang sa huli. Ito yung strongest suit ng trilogy. Great performances with great storytelling.Medjo may nitpick lang ako, kasi compared sa tatlo, ito yata ang pinaka-in your face ng reflections on what a Bayani is‚Äîin a sense na may long reflections si Joven or dialogue with Quezon and other characters, taking away the subtexts the audience should have get into. Medjo hindi ko nagustohan na may spoon-feeding na nagaganap sa pagkekwento‚Ä¶ At some point, gets ko naman kasi kahit nagbago ang body ni Joven (nagka-edad siya, as the epitome of a young nation), his soul still is young at kinakailangang tunggaliin ang paniniwala at iniisip niya with characters he can interact with sa pagdaloy ng kwento pero yun nga lang. Nakukuha nito ang experience sa audience sa pagponder on what a Bayani is.Initial thoughts ko lang naman ‚Äòto. Might do a second watch after having a refresher nung first 2 films.

A film about film relevant to the state of Philippines today. Imagine staring in front of a mirror and we do everthing we can to hide the blemishes. We focus on how we'll make ourselves look good for other people. Basically, the very make-up of the Filipino psyche. The film accurately represented the Filipino's inclination to the glamour and lavish lifestyle to escape the difficulty with Quezon as its charming figure greedy with dazzle and spotlight. Jericho Rosales was casted perfectly to sway the audience with just a smile and his sweet voice saying, mi querido. Quezon as the muse and political puppet master of the film was executed seamlessly, choreographed with the amazing editing transitions and the score of the film. It was as if the audience was pulled to keep up, and slowed down when the scene demands it. With an amazing cast ensemble, particularly the amazing supporting performances of Mon Confiado and Romnick Sarmenta that shadowed the dazzling light of Quezon. Every nuance of the actors was carefully and mindfully performed adding more to the depth of the film. Great fucking film! It was a breath of fresh air that makes you want to keep on watching.

The third film in the Bayaniverse series, Quezon, finally arrives a decade after Heneral Luna. Once again, Jerrold Tarog proves himself as an icon of Philippine cinema. As the film‚Äôs writer, director, editor, composer, and producer, Tarog demonstrates complete creative freedom. His distinct artistic voice resonates throughout the film. Tarog doesn‚Äôt shy away from drawing parallels between the political struggles of the past and the issues plaguing the Philippines today. It‚Äôs disheartening, as a Filipino, to realize how history continues to repeat itself, where those in power remain driven by greed and ambition.The film also challenges how we view Manuel L. Quezon. Was he truly a hero? Have we been blinded by the glorified version of our history, knowing only the good side of his leadership? These questions lingered with me long after the credits rolled.Visually, Quezon excels. The production design beautifully transports viewers to the past, recreating the era with meticulous detail. I was especially excited to see Iain Glen, though I admit I was a bit disappointed by how limited his screen time was. Jericho Rosales, on the other hand, delivers a refreshing performance, showing a side of him we haven‚Äôt seen before.Still, I felt the film could have explored more, particularly Quezon‚Äôs pivotal role as the ‚ÄúFather of the National Language.‚Äù That historical thread seemed missing and could have added more depth to his character and legacy.Overall, I genuinely liked Quezon. While Heneral Luna remains my favorite, this film stands strong in its own right. It‚Äôs thought-provoking, relevant, and undeniably crafted with passion. Perhaps it could have benefitted from more time in production, considering it was shot earlier this year, but its brilliance still shines through.Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4.5/5) ‚Äî A brilliant and insightful look into our past that continues to speak to the present.

The shining stars of QUEZON are the charismatic performances, intricate impartiality and visceral storytelling. Its place in the Bayaniverse and the entire trilogy itself acts as a strong reminder of the country's implications of its actions and choices.Perspective is the game in the politics of this time - Quezon exploits it to his advantage; a businessman in essence, a fiery public speaker, a charismatic strategist, thus leading him to power. Rosales captures the eponymous character with such gusto, power and dynamicism. One could say he indeed was Quezon in the flesh.But, this is still the Bayaniverse. Through journalist Joven Hernando, plus his filmmaker daughter Nadia in this film, provide an impartial lens where the modern audience is their envoy. Hernando's arc through the trilogy has satisfyingly gone full circle. Powerful for a fictional character in this context.Quezon brought this game - these political tricks, to light. Then us, the current generation, young and old, can still feel its heat. But at this point, it's a sprawling fire, unable to control. Is the future actually equipped enough to take it down? Ultimately, that's for us to decide.This film leaves viewers in deep critical thinking, as what this trilogy has gone out to do, and they've done it triumphantly. Between the humor, lightheartedness and cinematics, the questions confidently linger through, lasting long after the credits roll.

If you haven't watched the first two movies of the Bayani series, I suggest you should. Although it did not affect the understanding for this movie, you'll have a better grasp of the other important character's background. Jericho Rosales is an actor you should look out for. He put a lot of effort duplicating Manuel L. Quezon, especially the way he speaks. I think being able to change the way you speak for a 2-hour movie is dedication‚Äî Jericho has a lot of that. My last memory of watching Jericho Rosales was in a romance movie and I almost forgot how good he is. (Ito na magtatagalog na ako bdjsjsj) Nagulat ako kasi for someone na matagal nang hindi nakikita sa TV, sobrang pasabog ng pinakita niya na acting. This one really deserves to be in line with the other two Bayani movies. Sobrang galing din ng ibang actors as they also gave justice to the development of Manuel's character. Romnick wow! I already know he was an A-list actor, but seeing him with the others just made him stand out more (also maybe because he is an important character, but nonetheless). Mon, Karylle, Therese, Aaron, Cris, Joross, Ketchup, and JC were also freaking great. Ang lupit talaga ng line up ng artists kasi saan ka makakakita ng movies na kasama silang lahat? Sa Quezon lang. If you want to properly understand why we have this kind of government today, go watch Quezon and reflect as to why that kind of mindset persisted until today. It did not meant to make the people see Manuel as a hero, rather, it wants to make us realize why a revolution happened in the first place. It did not come from merely opposing a person‚Äî it is the generational urge to be in a better place that we can call ours. If politics is indeed a game, what choice do we have, as pawns, if we don't fight back and make a stand? Manuel Quezon was a not a good leaded nor a good politician, but let me quote what he said as a Filipino: "I am the Filipino people! I am the Philippines!"

the movie was really good ‚Äî it had so many surprising plot twists from the past. It‚Äôs fascinating to think that small actions could have changed history, like how if emilio had properly introduced quezon‚Äôs ‚Äúmistress,‚Äù he might have won the election back then.

this is joven‚Äôs film as much as it is quezon‚Äôs. i appreciate how the film is a conversation between someone‚Äôs frenetic and charismatic rise to power and someone‚Äôs silent descent to hero-worship and loss of objectivity in the face of stability and comfort brought by the former. joven, i hope i don‚Äôt become a mirror of you. i really hope i don‚Äôt.for in the end, one question remains: sarili o bayan?

The movie Quezon shows how patronage politics started in the Philippines. It‚Äôs a plea for people to always be critical because not everything is as it seems, especially when power and politics are involved. Dakila ang paglilingkod, but we can‚Äôt deny that even the brightest minds, no matter how noble their intent, have their own interests to protect, whether it‚Äôs power, greed, or pride. The film also leans into the idea of politics as performance, where charisma and public image often overshadow truth. It blurs the line between sincerity and spectacle, showing how easily stories can be staged, not just on screen, but in history itself. Beyond its message, this film feels like a love letter to the older forms of cinema now rendered obsolete by technology. In a world full of unfinished or half-hearted stories, it's admirable that Quezon made it to the screen despite all the odds. The more I think about the state of film today, the more I realize how fragile the whole industry is. The infrastructure is massive, and if one part of it falls, whether it‚Äôs funding, distribution, or technological support, the whole system would crumble.Watching Quezon in theaters felt like joining a fight to keep cinema alive. But it also made me realize that in a world where storytelling is changing rapidly, staying critical of what we consume is more important than ever. As technology brings new voices and narratives, we must stay aware of how stories are shaped. Quezon shows how the politics behind a film can influence its message, reminding us to be conscious of the contradictions in storytelling, especially with complex topics like politics.

It's all fun a games for our politicians while the Filipino people continue to be the pawnsWhen I saw the trailer for the first time I was a bit confused. Why were they using a Filipino children's game song in the trailer? It all made sense after watching the film.Quezon did not have the action and angst of its co-Bayaniverse film Heneral Luna nor it did not have the suspense and romanticization of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral but what it did have is a very intentional unraveling of a revered historical figure. This third Bayaniverse film is probably the best and my most favorite.From the very beginning of the film it captures you with its unique treatment of blending in a non-linear narrative with the meta-ness of using silent films as a medium to tell the story while it being contained in its own film. I admit at first there was some confusion in terms of the timeline and the determination of what is reality in the case of the film but as I patiently watched, it all meshed together really well. The end product was so good!I was waiting on moments where I could point out "show-don't-tell" moments but the expositions and explanations of what happened were really visualized and conveyed in such creative manners. Was it info overload? Well, if you didn't have any background/knowledge on Philippine History, it will be. But still, it's not a reason for someone to not watch it cause it will make you understand.Jericho Rosales, Karylle, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado really stood out. Manuel Quezon was personified through Jericho Rosales' effortless and magnetic performance. He embodied the late president so flawlessly. Karylle's Aurora Quezon was so specific and precise with her portrayal. Her eyes spoke a thousand words and she made us gravitate towards her in every scene she was in.Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osme√±a was a crowd-favorite. The eventual first Visayan President was performed with charm and likeability. Even sometimes stealing the scene away from Quezon.But my favorite performance in the film was Mon Confiado's Emilio Aguinaldo. I don't know if I'm being biased because my great grandfather was one of his secretaries but the way Emilio Aguinaldo was written and performed in this film is so complete and really bookends his character arc since he was first seen on Heneral Luna. What I love most about this film is that it vilifies no one but at the same time it does not champion anyone as well. Yes, Quezon was a really influential and well-loved president. Dare I say, the first true performative-male. And in a country where celebrity and politics win the votes of the people, he really, admittedly, played a good game. If he was in Game of Thrones he could've sat on the Iron Throne. It did not smear Quezon's name in any way, yet, it revealed to us who he really was and how he played the game.I keep going back to "game" cause this was basically the main theme of the film. A poker-playing politician who always aim to one-up his foes, and even friends. He played the game right but at what cost. People being stuck between colonialism and independence, propaganda against the heroes who fought for our freedom, and a never-ending cycle of patronage politics that was mentioned in the film.I'm so glad I watched this film and I learned about this. And what's funny is that the silliness that happened during their time is still the same silliness happening in our politics up to this date. Senators and congressmen further delaying our countries progress, pork barrels and nepobabies, the "utang na loob" culture in politics, all of these are still happening today.Now it gets me questioning whether the fight they fought was really a success or are we just in a new hell created by being collateral damage from their wars. I guess to end this on a positive note, at least now we have people waking up, we have strong journalist and filmmakers ready to be the voice of truth, and the Filipinos are now desperate for a change. may this film be one of the flames that will truly ignite our fight for a better life and TRUE INDEPENDENCE here in our country.
