Good movie that is carried by its excellent performances and undeniable timeliness. It does a good job of paying reverence to the Quezon‚Äôs legitimate political savviness while also depicting the back and forth of the political game as something childish and worthy of contempt. The movie is at its best when Jericho Rosales fires on all cylinders by being as abrasive and forceful as possible. Its these scenes, where Quezon seems deathly close to crashing out without actually doing it, where you can‚Äôt help but be mystified by his character, while simultaneously growing increasingly tired of him.The biggest problem with the movie is the problem with all the Bayaniverse movies, and a lot of movies in general nowadays, which is that it cannot help but over-explain. I get it, Manuel Quezon doesn‚Äôt exactly have the most well-known biography, but I feel like there‚Äôs a bit of projection that the audience won‚Äôt be able to understand the story without all the narrative cues, or the themes without the use of Joven as a narrator. Perhaps im more optimistic about Filipino literacy than i should be, but at some point, Jerrold Tarrog just needs to trust the audience. Joven is an incredibly lazy storytelling device that he has used as a crutch for three movies now, and made this movie twenty minutes longer than it should‚Äôve been. I don‚Äôt need him to tell me what the movie is trying to say, and we can‚Äôt train audiences to be more literate if he keeps telling them. If Joven still somehow shows up in the next movie despite ostensibly being over a century old by then, please either end the cinematic universe as a whole or reveal that he was Juan Ponce Enrile the whole time.

Jerrold Tarog's Quezon isn't just a historical biopic; it's a masterclass in political drama and the long-awaited final word in the Bayaniverse trilogy. This film brilliantly connects the trilogy, giving us the clearest and most satisfying explanation yet for the complex state of Philippine politics and leadership.At the heart of this engrossing narrative is Jericho Rosales' magnetic performance as Manuel L. Quezon. Rosales embodies the former president as a charismatic, cunning, and fiercely intelligent political operator. He portrays the energy, oratorical flair, and sheer force of will that defined Quezon, making it clear why this complicated, flawed man was able to navigate the brutal political game and change the course of history. It's a powerhouse portrayal that anchors the entire film.The fear in a dialogue-heavy historical film is a dragging pace, but Quezon defies it. The film moves with precision and purpose, making its runtime feel taut and engaging. You'll find your eyes peeled and attention held by the intense political maneuvering.This is history not as a dusty textbook, but as a live, urgent confrontation with power, compromise, and charisma. It confirms that the greatest battles for the nation were not just fought on the battlefield, but in the corridors of power.
love the political drama & hint of wes anderson influence. (-) for cong df

Hindi ako kulangot, wag mo akong binibilog. This film is or at least tries to be everything: a biopic, period drama, political satire, hays code era slapstick, old man yaoi, telenovela etc. Despite the seemingly conflicting tones, Jerrold Tarog and the creative team was able to juggle with grace and precision the different facets of Manuel Quezon and a nation's coming of age. Jericho Rosales is a revelation in his portrayal of the titular role. He spoke Tagalog in a slightly high-pitched almost-comical voice, and would switch to English in the accent of a timog-katagalugan everyman combined with the transatlantic cadence of a prohibition era radio personality. Equal parts charming and ruthless, hysterical and terrifying, he treated the character of Quezon as a ringmaster, and the Philippine Legislature his three-ring circus. As with the two other entries in Bayaniverse, Quezon holds a cinema screen-sized mirror to its audience as it peels away the layers of the man who planted the seeds of trapo culture in the Philippines. This is as much a character study of Quezon as it is of Joven, the makabayan surrogate character present in all three films, as he realizes in a full circle moment that even he and his uncompromising ideals of the Philippines' independence are susceptible to propaganda. Jerrold Tarog made a bold creative choice to cast deeper doubts on the conspiracies surrounding the murders of Andres Bonifacio and General Luna. He asks us viewers to look beyond the historical narratives we accept as facts, and to make wiser decisions on who we should put on the pedestal next as a hero of the nation.

"Hindi ako kulangot, 'wag mo akong binibilog."Bilang isang tambay ng sinehan, naalala ko na nakalagay sa trailer ng Quezon na it is "the last chapter in our quest to define bayani". So pagkatapos panoorin nito, mapapaisip ka nalang talaga: ano nga ba ang bumubuo sa isang bayani? Paano nga ba nagiging bayani ang isang tao? Pinakagusto kong desisyon na ginawa nila ay yung pagpapakita ng bagong paraan sa pagdefine ng "bayani". Kung sa Heneral Luna at Goyo ay nakita natin ang mga digmaan at ang laban para sa kalayaan ng Pilipinas, dito naman sa Quezon, ang sandata na ginamit para sa pagpapatuloy ng laban para sa kalayaan ay pananalita. Totoo na medyo mali nga lang yung paggamit nun ng iba sa movie na to huhuhfsdsa pero alam mo yun marina gets mo na yun matanda ka na.Di rin nahiya yung movie na ipakita ang dalawang panig ni Manuel Quezon at kung ano ang mga ginawa niya para lang makamit ang paulit-ulit na tinutukoy na "independensiya" ng bansa, kasabay ng kapangyarihang lagi niyang ninanais at di niya kayang bitawan. May kakaunting labo kung saan pumapanig ang pelikula pagkatapos ng lahat, pero nagulat na rin ako na ganun kalayo ang inabot nila sa pagpapakita ng pati na rin ang mga kasamaan niya.Ang nakalulungkot nga lang ay sabi dalawang beses dito na "out with the old, in with the new" (di ko naintindihan yung talagang sinabi nila sa tagalog sorry), pero wala pa ring nagbabago eh... ganito pa rin galawan ng mga pulitika. Yung pagbabago na hinahanap natin, hinahanap din nila noon, kaya if anything, sana magamit ang pelikulang ito upang patuloy na gumising ang mga tao at mamulat ang mga mata nila sa katotohanan ng lahat ng gulong ito, at kung sino ang mga may tunay na pananagutan sa lahat ng ito.
If this trilogy wasn't already giving us mixed signals on how to feel about our country, it certainly is now.

really really good film and a wonderful ending to this bayaniverse trilogy. it reminded me of Nick Joaquin's A Question of Heroes - like a deep dive into the people behind the heroes, asking the question: what does "bayani" really mean - are these heroes even real, or are they only heroes because of how the narratives of history have shaped them out to be? the performances, cinematography, the blocking, costuming, set design, color grading, soundtrack, and sound design are all absolutely a treat to watch. despite not being as action-packed as Heneral Luna and Goyo, it never feels dull because of how the screen is filled with life. watching this just after Hamilton was very interesting too, what with colonialism and independence being common themes. at the end of the day, they are both stories about flawed people who shaped the history of their respective nations, yet were also shaped by their skewed beliefs and the people and circumstances around them. overall a very very good and thought-provoking movie and I can't wait to rewatch it!

An ambitious film that tries a nuanced form of storytelling for an audience consisting of mostly high school graduates. Despite this, the movie is very engaging. It is firm in its stance on the character of the people in its story, but is intentionally ambiguous in its presentation of information on which there is no conclusive truth. Just like its predecessors, it is able to open conversation about topics which are relevant to ongoing affairs in the country; though perhaps this is simply reflective of the fact that the Filipino people have not learned from their history.Jericho Rosales shows the growth in his range as an actor with this film. This is easily one of his best, if not his best, performances ever. The other major characters in the film are able to hold their own ground here as well, though the minor characters show the clear difference in their level of skill.Great film.

Unfortunately, I haven't watched any of the Bayaniverse until this one. Well, it's an impulsive one for me to watch it but it's good to have it as somehow my last film before flying to the US and also, my first time at the director's club in our local cinema.I do not remember any moment where I felt so much giddy, excitement and anticipation watching a historical film but with this one, this excited me so much, amplified by the plethora (PLETHORA?!?!) of great actors (Rosales, Sarmenta, Santos, Lorenzo, Confiado, Villanueva, Tatlonghari-Yuzon, Abad Santos, Bayani, etc.) that just simply serve masterclass in acting and projecting. Jericho Rosales' portrayal of Quezon, from his demeanor up to his accent, it reminded me of how Vic Robinson portrayed Emilio Jacinto, that also shares an accent, it will really give you that good cherry on top for their characterizations.I really loved how the film was very rhythmic. That's the only word that comes to mind as the progression of the storylines per act is mainly governed by its accompanying track that somehow engages you to a certain feeling they want to invoke from you and that gives me so much fun because it really keeps me up and keeps me so engage, waiting for what's to come. But the accompanying track also somehow fasttracks certain transitions that make the flow of the story a little disorienting at times. There are moments where I am confused on what timeline it is or what reality it is. If I am in before of after Quezon's presidency or if I am in the silent movie created by Nadia or the reality alone.But beyond that, this is a good one and I can't wait to see both Heneral Luna and Goyo in the next few following days to see where this has started. p.s. How sad it is for the audience to realize that the reality of the Philippines in its early times is still the reality of the Philippines in the current times.

Absolute Pinoy Cinema. The style, cinematography, the lines, it's beautiful and charismatic. I felt like I travelled through time during the whole movie especially on the old film sequences, it made me feel like I was watching from an old cinema. I can almost smell the setting, specifically the wood elements from the interior scenes and I can also feel the warmth of the exterior scenes during the day. This may be the first time I felt magic in the cinema.In addition, the way the story was build from start to finish, I don't know how to describe it but it's like Oppenheimer with a hint of Wes Anderson's quirkiness from The French Dispatch. This film is 2 hours long but I do not recall a dull moment. If I'm to pin point this film's flaw, it's obviously Cong's cameo lol.I just love this film very much, can't wait to see what's next.

Some moments it feels like a sparknotes entry on Quezon's career rather than a far more deeper look into these events and how it affects him. In hidisght tho, Jericho Rosales managed to do Quezon so well that his visuals never really distract me. If there is going to be a Ramon Magsasay film, hopefully it will be the same approach as this one because I do not want a film that is only showcased the "heroism" of Magsasay but rather the consequences of a Magsaysay" (basically politicians tried to emulate his charisma and personality). Also a more deeper look in the chaoticness of the Third Republic

Jones Law. Tydings‚ÄìMcDuffie. Commonwealth. Republic. First president. The film playfully turns these terms we learned in school into a clear, engaging source of politically-charged cinematic plot. The sets are impressive and elevate the viewing (something we now often see in recent Pinoy history films), but focusing mostly on them would be a disservice to a competently written and made film. I was entertained, with twists that made familiar Sibika lessons feel new.Lowkey and right after watching Cinemartyrs from Cinemalaya, Quezon is another film that champions women in the early history of Philippine cinema. Similarly from Cinemartyrs, it also considers America's influence on the country, for better or worse. Independence still feels like a concept, and it has fostered a culture of gratitude that can imply a sense of inferiority, even up to now. Jerrold Tarog always has something to say about these things, showing how far people will go for power. Change the world or seek power or both, it's the same old story. Even before Philippine independence, that was the world. Nothing new there, but it is a welcome reminder.Seems like Jerrold Tarog is not just done yet. And that should be exciting. Although like our thoughts about Villeneuve making franchise films, it would be nice to see Tarog go back to modernly-set films. Maybe it's just a phase and this isn't new for directors locally or internationally.

This started like a history lecture and ended like a political slap. Yes, the film took its time finding rhythm - the first act felt like homework - but once the narrative locked in, it came alive and the payoff was rich. Jericho Rosales embodied Quezon with charm and danger, while Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs vision made history pulse with urgency. The way he balanced the film‚Äôs shifting tones was masterful. The film‚Äôs commentary on politics and power was cutting, the visuals lush, and its relevance terrifyingly familiar. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs important.

This was so good that I genuinely did not want this to end...Saan ba ako magsisimula? Napakaganda at napakahusay nito. Nakakatuwang manood ng pelikula kapag halata na ang mga taong lumikha nito ay mahal ang ginagawa nila and the works that have come before them. Unang eksena pa lang ay I knew I was going to be in for a treat. Sa huling eksena ay alam kong this is going to be bigger than a lot of us would think it will be. Napaka-entertaining. Balanseng balanse ang drama at comedy. Ang bawat aspeto ay maganda - script, cinematography, casting, at iba pa. And wow all that attention to detail. The evident change in the music in that scenes to the normal ones (ayokong ispoil LOL), yung transition pa-B&W??? Sobrang husay. At more importantly, napapanahon ang pelikulang ito. Di lamang ito tungkol sa buhay ng isang Presidente ngunit nagpapakita rin ito ng bagong paraan ng komentaryo sa mga isyu ng politiko at ng lipunan.And we NEED to talk about Jericho Rosales. Boy I'll get you that FAMAS and Urian I PROMISE!!!! Grabe ang galing. The way that he talks, he stands, he smiles, those tiny nuances, I was genuinely seeing Quezon on the big screen. Minsan ay di ako makafocus sa diyalogo dahil sobrang focused ko kay Jericho LOLThis was such a fun movie. We've got a classic on our hands truly. A true love letter to filmmaking and Filipino history.

Quezon isn‚Äôt just another film. It‚Äôs a bridge between the raw, emotional grit of indie cinema and the accessibility of mainstream storytelling. At its core, it‚Äôs a story about a protagonist who feels more like an anti-hero. Quezon could easily fit the mold of a Marvel villain, his intentions are clear and rooted in conviction, but he‚Äôll do whatever it takes to achieve them. It‚Äôs all about perception, really, and how morality can shift depending on where you stand. Di siya masamang tao. Pero willing siya gawin ang lahat. Para sa kanya or para sa bayan niya? On the technical side, the film shines. The use of parallelism, the sharp direction of Jerrold Tarog, and the deliberate framing from Pong‚Äôs cinematography all reflect a meticulous attention to detail. As an aspiring filmmaker and cinephile, you‚Äôll find yourself appreciating every choice they made; nothing feels accidental.The performances are equally impressive. Every actor fully embodies their role, responding naturally to one another. There‚Äôs no unnecessary showboating, no scene-stealing, just grounded, organic acting that serves the story.Emotionally, Quezon hits hard. It‚Äôs not an easy watch, but it‚Äôs a necessary one. The film mirrors the pain and complexity of the times we live in. It feels like an origin story for where we are as a nation today.As a frustrated creative from the Philippines, this is the kind of film that makes you proud. Quezon is proof that we can create something deeply cinematic, intelligent, and emotionally resonant, something that can stand proudly on the international stage.

Great filmmaking. Great shots. Great music. Great editing. But I felt nothing. Was I supposed to conclude that corruption, manipulation and politics go together since time immemorial? Don't I know that already? Doesn't everyone? And even if I did not, if that was all that I needed to realize by film's end, that was not much. That information could have been good for a documentary to explore and analyze. This drama bored me because it was not dramatic enough. A tragic figure, who doesn't change or is pulled further into sad or wrong choices, has to be set up as someone who seems heroic or as one who is given a chance to change his ways by the middle of the film. For all its freneticism, it droned. I think it wanted to be entertaining like a Scorsese or a Chazelle, but the writing caused a pacing problem. Also wondered if anyone who did not have an idea of who Quezon was would be invested in knowing why this is important to see for any human being. I wish all this technique was used on a good screenplay.

"Bayan o sarili, pumili ka?"The Bayaniverse may have ultimately been a series of movies that are (if not for the same cast members/ completely standalone, but the bigger picture it paints is asking us the same question John Arcilla's Heneral Antonio Luna once asked a decade ago: "Bayan o sarili?""Heneral Luna" is about a man who is dedicated to giving the country its rightfully earned freedom, no matter who he has to piss off to get it."Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral" is about a man who ultimately takes the fight, despite his selfish and somewhat childish nature."Quezon" is about a man who is nothing but a slimy and greedy politician who uses the country's independence as a bargaining chip so he can gain power and keep it for as long as he lives.The movie tells us outright that Quezon is not a good man, nor is he the hero of this story. He is a villain who uses every dirty trick in the book to remain one step ahead. It paints a picture of Quezon that is all too familiar to the everyday Filipino: a politician who plays dirty games to gain sympathy so they can climb higher into power.I love how Joven Hernando, who has always been the audience surrogate, has become a more active participant in the story. He becomes one of Quezon's pawns, another piece he could use to further his agenda. And once Joven reverts to his roots and once again becomes an observer, that's when the rug is pulled from under him.Joven is human. He is just like the "heroes" we've followed throughout the trilogy, flawed.Quezon brings the Bayaniverse into a solid finish, bringing back everything that came from Luna and Goyo all so it can ultimately tell the big punchline: Aguinaldo outlived every single one of the people we've followed in this trilogy.The Bayaniverse doesn't treat each and every single one of its focus as a holier-than-thou hero, but rather, humans who are just as flawed as everyone else. And in this landscape where every other biopic in the Philippines is treated like a glorified Wikipedia list, it's a breath of fresh air.Now, nobody knows what happens after this movie, after Bayaniverse. Who knows, maybe the Magsaysay tease could lead into a new trilogy that once again examines the Philippines and how we've become who we are today. Whether that happens or not, I'm glad we got to see these three movies come to life, the long way round. And if this does lead to another trilogy of movies, you know where I'll be.(P.S. Docking one star because the movie's soundtrack is sang by the jootsex guy.)

One of those movies you are just so incredibly engrossed in that you don‚Äôt even realize how long it actually is To utilize a film within a film was amazing to watch because of its simple yet amusing execution, not to mention its accuracy and relevance during that time. To see lessons and personalities I once learned in class brought to life was all the more fun‚Ä¶ na para bang napapanood ko na lahat unfold with my own two eyes ! And lastly, to see the mischievous games and calculated steps & agenda that transpire within the government was insane, funny, compelling, nakakagalit, nakakainis, and overall nakakagulo ng isip kasi hindi mo alam sino papanigan mo‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Which is the point. These political leaders are meant to be humanized. They are complex and abundant of fault. Sabi nga ni Quezon, in order to lead the nation in prosperity he needs to get his hands dirty from time to time. Everyone in this cast was remarkable, lalo na sina Jericho Rosales and Romnick Sarmenta. Their performance in this film gave justice to the brilliance of Quezon, as well as Osme√±a. All in all, napakahusay talaga. As usual. Everyone watch Quezon. PLEASE. Sobrang importante ng pelikulang ‚Äòto especially in a time where political games and corruption remain to prevail. Hindi siya yung typical bayaniverse movie na puno ng giyera, but this one resonates more with the current times which just justifies how crucial it is to watch this NOW. A long, amoral dance between people who enjoy playing dirty games. Beautifully shot and wonderfully acted‚Äîas my partner remarked, it was less of a board game and more of a sarswela.The narrarive itself could‚Äôve trimmed a lot of fat. It felt like the makers wanted to provide all relevant facts while at the same time letting the people decide for themselves. I think that if this series hadn‚Äôt gotten too meta, too self-conscious about its actual effect on Philippine society, it could‚Äôve really been more courageous and straightforward.Hearing Jericho Rosales speak was jarring at first‚Äîhaving known him as an affable romantic lead‚Äîbut he dissolves into his playful characterization. Women were also there, but they didn‚Äôt really do much to move the story along, or at all participate in it‚Äîperhaps a choice in storytelling, and a subconscious tendency that may need to be reflected on.All in all, extremely fun!

What a beautifully shot film that screams ‚Äúsarswela‚Äù from start to end. As remarked by my partner, political dramas told by pinoys for pinoys are best presented in a comedic angle with the frequent spoonfeeding just to make sure the audience is caught up. This is personified by Joven‚Äôs character with the insistent need to have a third person pov to narrate the story (similar to Himala‚Äôs Orly), rather than just showing the events for what they are, otherwise the narrative can‚Äôt be controlled. Further amplified in the scene of Wood asking if Filipinos actually understood what ‚Äúindependence‚Äù truly meant. Maybe that‚Äôs the point of sandwiching humor (today: memes) in the gravity of our political state, it‚Äôs still relevant to the sarswela we have in the government today.The theme of storytelling through film does hit a very important mark in this trilogy‚Äî how heneral luna influenced the rise of a strongman president, and how it circled back in this third installation portraying the power of politcal alliances, uniteam. Haha. I do want to point out how so filipino movie-coded this is, with, of course, using women‚Äôs suffering as a plot device to move men‚Äôs story forward! How necessary was it to use a rape case other than as a threat and show the title character as cocky(we already know that), or how it‚Äôs scandalous that he‚Äôs bigamous (we already know that), or how aurora is complicit to all these. And, at the end, bears nothing to the story. Honestly, all those parts could‚Äôve been cut from the film and it would have still held up. Lastly, I was first distracted looking at Jericho Rosales and not think of Echo the Hunk. By the end of the film he was truly Quezon to me. Anyway, mambo, mambo, magsaysay!

I can never forget the optional reading given to us in Kasaysayan 1 class by Prof. Karl Poblador. It was Alfred McCoy‚Äôs paper ‚ÄúQuezon's Commonwealth: The Emergence of Philippine Authoritarianism‚Äù. I was shocked at first at how absurd the title seemed. Quezon being the blueprint of dictators like Ferdinand Marcos Sr. and Rodrigo Duterte seemed like a stretch.The common Filipino mostly associates Manuel L. Quezon with positive things. The Father of Philippine Independence. The face on the P20 bill. Ama ng Wikang Pambansa. Namesake of the most populous (maybe even the best) city in the country. Strangely though, historical films about the struggle for Philippine independence rarely focus on the life of the first President of the Commonwealth. There are countless cinematic imaginations of figures like Jose Rizal, Andres Bonifacio, and Emilio Aguinaldo. But I can only remember one film about Quezon, the very bland Schindler‚Äôs List knock off Quezon‚Äôs Game. Quezon is portrayed as a stoic hero, allowing Jewish people to seek refuge as Nazis and World War II circle in on the country. After reading McCoy and watching Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs film, that film even looks worse. Tarog‚Äôs Quezon is what exactly the country needs right now. A repudiation of the myth of a ‚ÄúGreat Man‚Äù and his legacy. A stark reminder of the illusion of Philippine independence and the role of native elites in perpetuating the very system the foreign colonizers used for subjugation. The election race between Aguinaldo and Quezon, framed as a battle between the old and the new, even resembles the upcoming 2028 presidential race between the Marcos and the Duterte dynasties. A choice between two evils. The screenplay is impressive in its weaving of multiple timelines in Quezon‚Äôs political career, examining the key relationships (Sergio Osme√±a, Emilio Aguinaldo, Leonard Wood, the fictional Joven Hernando) that defined it. It reminds me of The Social Network and Oppenheimer in its nonlinearity, an always welcome structure compared to the dominant cradle to grave biopic structure. Black and white 1930-style sequences, featuring the best looking shots of an otherwise blandly photographed and colored film, frame the entire narrative. And it is here where Tarrog‚Äôs screenplay surprises in its examination of the role of cinema in political propaganda and collective imagination. Joven, the Bayaniverse‚Äôs audience surrogate, finally becomes a compelling character, as he wrestles with supporting Quezon‚Äôs presidency.The humorous tone is another welcome approach, playing up the ironies of Quezon‚Äôs political decisions from being a collectivist ideologue to supporting the working class to slightly changing an independents act to take credit away from Osme√±a. The tone is a good contrast to the rather dull self seriousness of the preceding Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral. Quezon is a comical figure: a petty, narcissistic, scheming con artist. A far cry from the image of a noble patriot many have. Jericho Rosales radiates an almost DiCaprio-like energy and charisma; the loudness of Rosales‚Äôs Quezon, in his verbal sparring and speeches, masks the shallowness of his intentions for independence.Tarrog‚Äôs screenplay does flounder with the theme of the hollowness of Philippine independence. ‚ÄúDo you know what independence means?‚Äù, asks Governor-General Wood to peasant Filipino farmers. The scene seems to be played for laughs at the expense of Filipinos who are portrayed as having a simplistic understanding of the meaning of freedom. Rather than further visualize the plight of working class Filipinos, the film does relegate them to the margins. The formation of Quezon City, the planned home for Manila‚Äôs laborers, is a pivotal moment in Quezon‚Äôs political career and the country‚Äôs history. And yet, the film omits or does not tackle what would have been a perfect illustration of Quezon‚Äôs contradictions. But, to the film‚Äôs credit, it is long enough already. Perhaps it‚Äôs best discussed by another film. Quezon is a rare biopic in this country. We‚Äôve had cinematic deconstructions of Filipino heroes like Rizal and Aguinaldo already. But never has there been a film that demystifies a supposed hero as nothing more than an egotistical opportunist ‚Äî not unlike the greedy and insincere politicians at the center of the ongoing DPWH flood control investigation. Even if the film has flaws in its bland cinematography and visualizing the struggle of working class Filipinos, it‚Äôs hard for me to not be riled up after watching Tarrog‚Äôs Quezon. That‚Äôs great enough for me.

The movie, ‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù by Jerrold Tarog completes the so-called BAYANIverse trilogy that also includes ‚ÄúHeneral Luna‚Äù and ‚ÄúGoyo: Ang Batang Heneral‚Äù. The trilogy (post-credit suggests a fourth biopic) was designed to deconstruct the myth surrounding Philippine national heroes by portraying them as flawed and complex human beings rather than perfect heroes we place on pedestals.This is an enjoyable, brisk, and highly opinionated biopic on Quezon. Making a film about history in an entertaining manner is always a challenge but Tarog and co-screenwriter Rody Vera passed with flying colors with a screenplay that intricately weaves historical facts with cinematic storytelling. They did this with the masterful insertion of fictional characters Joven Hernando and his daughter Nadia Hernando. They also avoided the pitfall biopics usually fall into‚Äîpointlessly following a chronological order and trying to present everything. Here, they used Quezon's political skirmishes with Leonard Wood, Sergio Osme√±a and Emilio Aguinaldo to tell the story of the consummate politician.Kudos to Jericho Rosales for his portrayal of Quezon: temperamental, mercurial, and unpredictable. I had my doubts if he could pull it off when I saw the trailer but happy to have been proven wrong. He is at his best when attempting to charm his way out of a predicament and outwitting his adversaries. Quezon is undoubtedly a compelling and complex individual. ‚ÄúElastic, electric‚Äù; ‚Äúone of the world‚Äôs supplest and hardest-boiled practical politician‚Äù; these were some of the words used by John Gunther in an article for January 1939 issue of The Atlantic Monthly. But such reading of the man who became President of the Philippine Commonwealth, Gunther noted, was ‚Äúonly a fraction of the complex, composite truth‚Äù. The movie portrays Quezon as Machiavellian‚Äîscheming, manipulative, and self-interested. He bossed legislators using the largesse at his disposal, and by threatening them with political ostracism. He valued the loyalty and gratitude of those around him. He would reward those who helped and followed him with jobs and pensions. This is clearly portrayed in his relationship with Emilio Aguinaldo, whose farm and pension he took away when the latter dared to run against him in the country‚Äôs first ever elections. But Quezon was also ‚Äúa genuine revolutionary‚Äù as Gunther noted, ‚Äúthe history of the Philippine Islands in the twentieth century and the biography of Manuel Quezon are indissolubly one‚Äù. He was also loved by the masses because of his support for the marginalized. He was the one who set minimum wages for government laborers, established an eight-hour working day, and slapped higher taxes on the rich. I had to rewatch Heneral Luna and Goyo before watching Quezon. I think the trilogy succeeded in reimagining these three heroes revealing more intricate, conflicted human beings. But I also hoped that the trilogy could have focused more on nation-building rather than personalities. I understand the need to focus on heroic personalities in these biopics but I hope viewers came out of cinemas not just thinking about heroes as history but also this: the road to nationhood and statehood is complicated. It is still unraveling today. It is still complicated.Saying that the Filipinos united against colonizers to fight for freedom and become one nation is naive. To be fair, Tarog hinted at this in Heneral Luna and Goyo by depicting the regional differences of the revolutionaries and how it contributed to Aguinaldo‚Äôs defeat. But can we blame the Ilocanos or the Kapampangans? The revolutionaries from the different regions were fighting for a nation that wasn't there yet. This was Jose Rizal‚Äôs obsession during his time‚Äîthe lack of a national consciousness. He spent, and offered, his life to lay the groundwork for a collective national identity, a shared sense of being a nation. Quezon was more pragmatic in his approach. He said, ‚ÄúIn statecraft the most important thing is the goal.‚Äù In other words, the end justifies the means. Quezon, of course, would never publicly admit that the goal of independence from the United States is intrinsically tied to ambition. To his mind, what hurt would it do if the national goal and his interest align? One of the most powerful moments in the film was when Joven was pontificating in front of Quezon, berating him for his greed and scheming ways. Quezon then turned the tables around telling Joven that he was in fact an accomplice because he also benefitted from Quezon. The US role in all these should not be diminished. By organizing local elections they essentially empowered local warlords to acquire power setting the stage for their capture of central government.There were instances when the movie relied too much on commentaries rather than storytelling. I really appreciate movies, especially those with political and social messages, that exercise restraint‚Äîwhen it does not tell us how to feel and what to think. Rather than spoon-feeding us it is more important to give us the opportunity to decide for ourselves.

This film is a sharp contrast to Henral Luna and Goyo, but somehow it blends in. It is the same game in a new mask‚Äîthe same battle in a different battlefield. It has always caught my interest that the Bayani-verse shows the humanity in figures revered by their good actions in the past. It grounds the character to a playing field in which we can analyze their actions and flaws as if they are not above us at all. It gives the audience space to ponder the differences between the praises given on history books and the reality of the human experience. Film is always such an amazing platform for storytelling in ways that capture essence and displays an overarching sense of humor in our lives even in serious moments.Quezon concludes the first battle by showing us that in war or in the pursuit of independence, politics has always been the same. It is rooted in tactics and is played out as a game. Battle of minds and leverage is the front of all this. A greater focus should be on the sequence in which they discuss the readiness of the country for independence. From now and then, the comprehension of concepts allows the nation to grasp what it wants. If the word independence could not be understood before, now it has ballooned to so much more. Terms that now hide from the public to understand. Watching this film, the people behind me were in shock when the word communist was mentioned. I knew there and then that they do not know the concept of this ideology much like the Filipinos that did not understand independence. In the very seats that welcome watchers is also the very seats that criticizes us. Anyways‚Äîpreparing for the teaser shown as a mid credit scene. I expect a lot considering the impact of the bayani verse to the film industry, to Filipino culture, and Philippine perception. Magsaysay!

‚ÄúMauuna pa atang pumuti ang uwak kaysa bitawan mo ‚Äòyang kapangyarihan mo.‚ÄùUnlike the first two installments of the Bayaniverse, Quezon throws all subtlety out the window and says everything straight to your face. I took an elective on the History of the Philippine Presidency last semester, and we spent almost half of it just talking about Quezon. Watching the film felt exactly like that ‚Äî a two-hour lecture where all the facts are dumped on you. Maybe that's not entirely a bad thing. Maybe it's better that there's no room for misinterpretation or assumptions of what the film wants to say. Maybe that's what we need as a nation: to be told, directly and unapologetically, what needs to be done for us to become better.Quezon feels painfully familiar because everything in it mirrors our current news cycle ‚Äî a political shitshow where those in power do everything to hold on to it. At first, it‚Äôs laughable. But eventually, it stops being funny, and we‚Äôre just left angry.We deserve better than someone like Quezon. We deserve better than leaders obsessed with themselves but blind to the people they‚Äôre supposed to serve. We deserve better than naming cities after them or printing their faces on our money. We need to stop turning flawed men into untouchable icons and start being honest about what their legacies should look like.Tarog‚Äôs meta-commentary in this third installment is interesting, but the constant switching between the younger and older versions of the characters can get confusing. I get what he‚Äôs trying to do. He wants us to remind that history can be reconstructed or reinterpreted, but sometimes it pulls the story away from having emotional or narrative depth.That said, the ensemble was great, but Karylle was especially exceptional. The unsure, restrained, and quiet glances she gives when the camera lingers on her say so much about a woman‚Äôs place in our nation‚Äôs fight for independence: sidelined and often overlooked. As her character tells his husband, ‚ÄúNaniniwala akong naniniwala kang tama ‚Äòyang pinaglalaban mo.‚ÄùWith Tarog‚Äôs Bayaniverse coming to a close (or is it?), it feels like the fight that should‚Äôve started long ago is only just beginning. Saying ‚Äúwe should fight‚Äù can get tiring and repetitive, but then again, maybe that‚Äôs why films like this still matter. Because we still see leaders like Quezon today. But those people aren‚Äôt the Philippines. We are.

Manuel Luis Quezon (Benjamin Alves as the younger version) inside the prison cell at the beginning of the film submits to a calling he himself invokes,an act of total surrender to the shining light of messianic delusion: he as a vanguard of freedom,a savior of the nation. This scene lays down the very blueprint of the man, and the DNA of the third film of Jerrold Tarog's Bayaniverse shown at such a time as this. Tarrog's deconstruction of Manuel Quezon easily reveals a pattern, the four chapters proving how the Commonwealth figure wields power. The film depicts Joven Hernando (Aaron Villaflor/Cris Villanueva) as the conflicted source of truth and keeper of lies, he being witness to the former and he being made to hide the latter. Quezon ought to strip Hernando of his journalistic freedom lest he (Hernando) destroy the masses' perception of the politician. Cassey, as the Americans call Quezon,orders silence as a tool that the film also uses to depict politics as a performance where Cassey plays the main part and masters it to perfection. Cassey's political campaign by way of showing silent films visualizes the performative act. A man plays someone he is not,living the dream so long as he has the power, so long as he is able to craft perception and accord himself the grandeur. His bouts against Sergio Osme√±a (Romnick Sarmienta), Leonard Wood (Iain Glenn), and Emilio Aguinaldo (Mon Confiado) easily reflect what we see today: politics as a game, interests at the center, power as the ultimate goal. The scene where Quezon walks back to his seat after his speech while Aguinaldo walks towards the podium projects a duel reflective of the political motion that haunts our nation: each going a different direction but aiming for the same peak of dominance.The score is aptly dramatic and haunting, giving the scene the verve that seals what we make of our politicians--if we haven't settled that yet.Jericho Rosales brilliantly plays Manuel Quezon as the Senate President and the President of the Commonwealth by consistently creating the identity of the man who cannot be caught defeated. His performance naturally shows Quezon as a larger-than-life figure, the center around which everything revolves. That the film depicts him in this magnitude makes everyone else small, especially the masses whom he declares he works for.But not only are they rendered small; they are also voiceless and invisible. When a poor man defines independence as food, the film unmistakably captures power and its fuel. It rightfully pictures the masses being the ultimate victims of the fraud that is politics, the victims of the insatiable dreams of the narcissists where they (masses) are subconsciously the empaths that support their (narcissists) fantasy.And so we laugh because the film is a farce as much as it is a political drama whose emotional interjection comes at the far end of the spectacle. It comes as a silent wave of heartbreak and desperation. For ourselves. For our nation. How else should the film show Quezon at the end but the way the film does? Did his dreams come true? At a point where he no longer has influence,what are the words that matter? The film serves the closure we deserve from a man we've come to know from the very beginning,the consistency Quezon can never make himself to break because his nature will never allow it. His last words affirm his fantasy.Saying "I am the Philippines" can never be more delusional. To this day, we continue to see this delusion. And it harms us more than ever.

Ahhhh. This movie is so good. I know that this is a story based on Quezon but this is just as timely as it could have been with all the political statements that they have showed us here. I think it is truly important to note how power can be intoxicating but we also have to be reminded as voters that we have power to put these people in positions. We should be more critical of them and make them understand that who they are serving are us and not themselves. The film also encapsulates how media can also be used to change narratives and we have seen that be weaponized in today's time as well. We need stories like these to remind us of where power should lie and how these politically corrupt actions can lead to our demise as a nation. There are good and bad sides to people but I think it is important to remember them both and not put anyone on a pedestal high enough for no one to reach them but instead make them understand where true power lies - in us. This is an amazing film with a strong lead performance by Rosales and an even stronger supporting cast to back him up.

I love this movie more than Goyo (2018). Hands down to Jerrold Tarog for creating this spectacular movie. With those editing and transitions, it feels like I‚Äôm watching a Coen Brothers‚Äô film, and in the writing, he stays true to his style. Round of applause to Jericho Rosales for his accent and acting skills. He was a revelation in this movie, and every shot of him is just amazing to watch and left me in awe. Romnick Sarmenta and JC Santos are also fun to watch; well done. Having Iain Glen on this, as Leonard Wood, is just perfect for the role. Mon Confiado reprising the role as Emilio Aguinaldo‚Äîit really does suit him. The cinephile in me is in pure joy and tickled by this movie.In terms of the history, as Mark Twain says, ‚Äúhistory repeats itself, but it often rhymes.‚Äù With the current situation in the Philippines, it reflects a lot, and it is sad to think that we‚Äôre in a cycle. The feeling that we‚Äôve never learned our lesson from the past. Quezon using independence for power to get into a higher position, and the way he acts, he is the epitome of a ‚Äútrapo.‚Äù With all things considered, it is hard to be a Filipino and to be hopeful that one day we will be able to elect someone who has a pure intention to help every Filipino and make decisions that are for the betterment of the Filipino people. Thank you, Jerrold Tarog, for continuing to create these movies. In this way‚Äîhopefully‚ÄîFilipinos will reflect and learn something from the past, see the current situation of our country, and make better decisions for the future of our country.

Film Review: Quezon (dir. Jerrold Tarog, 2025)When I was young, Manuel Quezon was a romanticized figure, hailed as the one who earned the Philippines its independence, and also the ‚ÄúFather of the National Language.‚Äù Aside from that, I really know nothing about that guy.Several years later, I came across a copy of Ambeth Ocampo‚Äôs ‚ÄúQuezon‚Äôs Sukiyaki,‚Äù a collection of essays about several historical figures in Filipino history. It contained some interesting notes on Quezon‚Äôs boisterous nature. Further readings unraveled Quezon‚Äôs more devious side as a politician, which was the main theme of Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs newest film.‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù chronicled the rise of the titular character from a veteran of the Filipino-American War to the president of the Philippine Commonwealth. The movie deviated from the typical depictions of the former president. Here we saw Quezon at his most unscrupulous, a true political chameleon. Whatever glazed images I had of the man evaporated after watching this movie. Suffice to say, Quezon was the original trapo. While it can be said that he genuinely cared about independence, he surely had his hands dirty, and his priority was after all, his own interests.Jericho Rosales was phenomenal in his role- adapting Quezon‚Äôs speech patterns and mannerisms. I was a bit skeptical when he was announced to be the lead, but Echo was a great actor after all and he surely proved it. Mon Confiado‚Äôs performance in this movie as Aguinaldo was a stark contrast from the other Bayaniverse films: the Aguinaldo in ‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù was more mellow, seemingly remorseful, softened by age. It was amazing of Mon to portray the same character in three different ways.The performance of the actors in this film was phenomenal, and I think everyone pulled their weight. I must specifically praise Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osme√±a. His bickering with Quezon was one of the film's highlights. I think ‚ÄúQuezon‚Äù was the most creative in all Bayaniverse films. I particularly liked the silent film snippets. It showed us the importance of media arts in shaping political opinions. I also appreciated the use of the rondalla as the main musical force of the movie: it made the movie sound more like a Filipino political comedy, compared to its militaristic predecessors. Compared to ‚ÄúHeneral Luna‚Äù and ‚ÄúGoyo‚Äù there were barely any action scenes in the movies. The battles were fought through verbal sparring, scheming, and persuasion. It was a unique Bayaniverse movie. I don't have many criticisms against this movie, although a certain cameo mildly soured my viewing experience. Also, I wish we saw more of the Japanese occupation, to see a different side of Quezon. I must say though, that the ending was hauntingly good. A great film, nonetheless.

I believe in the innocence of Tarog's intentions and artistry, and I stand by my opinion that he didn't foresee how his depiction of Luna will be used to amplify the evil spawn's charisma to the masses back in '16. Goyo tried to correct stuff but majority wasn't ready for its message then. Now, here comes the much awaited final film of the Bayani trilogy, at last.Quezon has a much refined commentary compared to the first two. It's well-paced. Couple of hours flew by quick. If Filipinos weren't brainwashed with fake news on a reel-to-reel basis for the past nine years, this film could've easily made an impact in our political landscape heavier than Luna ever did.Another quality film worth seeing in the big screen. It's just heartbreaking that several decades after Quezon's reign, the Philippines has yet to achieve true independence from traditional and patronage politics.

TANGINA ANG GALING NI JERICHOThe third and final installment of Tarog‚Äôs Bayaniverse trilogy is the best out of all of them in my opinion.Growing up, I have had this infallible‚Äîalmost immaculate image of former President Quezon in my mind. He was always dubbed as the ‚ÄúFather of the Filipino Language‚Äù and it didn‚Äôt help that he was my Grandpa‚Äôs favorite president ever. All I heard about Manuel was good things. This film shocked me, as the once perfect image I had of this ‚Äúgreat‚Äù man (and I put quotation marks on that word because iykyk) was systematically debunked by the exposition of all his flaws. Direct Tarog succeeded in humanizing this man.Jericho really disappeared in this role, as I was convinced that he was a direct 1:1 copy of Mr. Quezon himself. The mannerisms, the intensity, the accent; he nailed it and really captured the swagger of this ‚Äúgreat‚Äù man (again, iykyk).Mon Confiado is Mon Confiado, Rominick was great and very adorable as Osme√±a, Iain Glen was excellent also, despite only appearing briefly.I loved the music, the occasional slapstick comedy, and the silent film parts. Could have been 5 stars but I found some scenes a little confusing and if it weren‚Äôt for that CongTV cameo lol.

Simply an amazing film to end Tarog‚Äôs Bayani Trilogy. Quezon harnessed the strengths of its predecessors Heneral Luna and Goyo, producing a film with strong storytelling, great actors, and awesome cinematography. Although he did not physically look like the mestizo Casey, Jericho Rosales delivered an enigmatic performance well-deserving of acting awards. But among its merits, perhaps my favorite thing about Quezon is its pointed delivery of political critique not only towards the current administration but to the long history of corrupted, patronizing, and self-serving Philippine politics.I know for sure that it is not only me who feared that Quezon would end up sanitizing the former president‚Äôs image, as films about politicians and heroes tended to do so. But alas, Quezon was not usual biopic that mythologized the man ‚Äî instead, it demystified him, reintroducing the former President that plastered his and his wife‚Äôs name all over his home province and the biggest city in Metro Manila. It was able to effectively deliver Manuel Luis Quezon as the cunning politician, borderline dictator that he is.Alongside his intelligent spiels and populist rhetoric, the film revealed the unapologetic and manipulative character of the 2nd President of the Philippine Republic ‚Äî the man who laid the formula of political maneuvering for the politicians and would-be presidents after him, proving Alfred McCoy‚Äôs view that Quezon‚Äôs Commonwealth paved the way for Philippine authoritarianism.I do hope that Tarog continues to develop new historical fiction films in the future. More than ever, we need more films that tackle and communicate our history in interesting ways that provoke the audience to revisit our past and reexamine our stances on our ‚Äògreat‚Äô men.

This film was able to give the audience a stronger sense of discernment of Quezon‚Äôs politics and character through Joven, in ways that I had hoped was done through Heneral Luna. I need a rewatch of GOYO and HL.

Quezon closes out Jerrold Tarog's Bayaniverse as a farcical deconstruction of the idea that one "Great Man" can lead a nation to prosperity. With Joven as the audience surrogate of the trilogy, Tarog makes sure that this myth is shattered. We see Joven slowly but surely become disillusioned as he realizes the dangers of putting a face to a political movement. Gone are the days where he puts these strong and charismatic men on a pedestal. This film feels the most pointed of the trilogy. Tarog's screenplay feels quite self-conscious as it sometimes overexplains itself. This film really wants to make a point amidst today's political turmoil. Politics is a game. It paints Quezon as a charismatic yet narcissistic manipulator who knew how to play it so well that he may just be the showman who invented political chess. He's basically a glorified "trapo" who's tidied up by our history books with titles like "Ama ng Wikang Pambansa." His methods are the reason why Filipinos today are so swept up by populist and charismatic leaders. Whether we like it or not, his methods paved the way for the dominance of "trapos" in our Senate today. On the other hand, I feel like the lack of subtlety did remove the nuances and gray areas that I was looking for in a take like this. It does become just a fight between good and evil in some parts. For one, I did not understand the choice of glazing over Aguinaldo in this when even he lead a regime built upon manipulation. Felt like Tarog retracted from his stance against Aguinaldo in Heneral Luna where he was heavily villainized (deservedly so) in that third act. I also wanted more nuance with its take on Quezon himself. He was quite the showman who shifted his principles and narratives when it's convenient for him. I guess I just wanted more moments of self awareness and reckoning from him. Him being an egotistical maniac just felt a bit too clean and clear cut. Loved how Jericho Rosales just threw himself into this role though. Even if he is over the top, you really buy the charms and sales talking that he does in the film. Despite my gripes with it, I do think this is a refreshing historical biopic and I like how it played with its structure. It wants to make a point and it delivers with clarity and conviction. I ultimately do think this is a national hero biopic that we deserve right now as a nation. Something that will serve as a caveat and hopefully, an antidote to our deep fanaticisms with populists and demagogues.

Complicated film for a complicated man. Stellar performance from Jericho Rosales and the rest of the cast. I couldn‚Äôt side with anyone on the film and I think that‚Äôs the ultimate point. Quezon ultimately achieved independence for the country, but are we truly independent? Only main gripe was I wanted more of Aurora Quezon knowing her significant role post-Commonwealth but we may be getting that down the line instead.

Tarrog‚Äôs most scathing work on a historical figure yet. At times, it can border into the saccharine, but that can be forgiven in consideration of the necessity for its themes to be communicated to the widest possible audience. However, much less forgivable is that in establishing Quezon‚Äôs manipulative and underhanded methods in politics, it may have presented his contemporaries, even the Americans, in a less critical light. Quezon becomes so comically evil towards the end that he makes everyone else look like saints.And yet, even as you grow to despise Quezon more and more, Jericho Rosales‚Äô performance transfixes and commands attention. It should be praised that a portrayal that slimy and morally despicable continues to compel and leave you hanging on his every word. If not for the historical accuracy, a criteria I can‚Äôt attest to, watch this one for Rosales‚Äô performance alone.

Quezon is about the deconstruction of our first Commonwealth president. It is a fair and complex portrait of a man that seeks to use any means possible to achieve 'independencia' of course with much cost to the Philippines and its people. We are still paying for the crimes Quezon committed and the peak form of it has been achieved by no less than Duterte who couldn't even be moreso the antithesis to everything MLQ lectured upon. Jerico Rosales brings an exuding energy I haven't felt in any historical film in a long while. The versatile Mon Confiado nails Emilio Aguinaldo to a tee. The writing was great but too much at times. Directing did not overplay nor stumble in the length of Quezon's regime. Ultimately, body and soul was really the gameplay from the Battle of Tirad Pass to his death. Excellent pacing and terrific editing! This film is a must watch for all of us.

‚Äúa house divided against itself must fall‚Äù its been a few hours since i‚Äôve seen this film because i want to digest everything that i can from the film before writing a review. i haven‚Äôt seen the previous films in such a long time but i do think this is the best one from bayaniverse. this has been one of my most anticipated films this year and man it did not disappoint. since i saw the trailer i knew it was promising and seeing it today i can honestly say that it exceeded my expectations. i love that the movie didn't shy away from criticizing quezon and showing us exactly who he really is? unlike the books from school that made him look like a great man the way it did with that propaganda movie that nadia made for his presidential campaign. when it comes to history talaga you really do have to read more than what they teach you from school (and its books) because if you haven‚Äôt i think people would've been so shocked at how disgusting and evil quezon is. quezon is exactly the reason why we have the type of politicians we have now, it started with him and it‚Äôll continue to infiltrate the government as years goes by if we don‚Äôt do anything about it. a chameleon who changes its skin with every person he interacts with, even his own wife and friends to reap its benefits. to quezon the country is just a game to be played with and as long as it makes him look good and he comes out at the top he will continue to play that game until his last breath, hence, ‚ÄúI am the Philippines‚Äù.incredible incredible acting performance from every single actors in this cast especially jericho rosales who is undoubtedly the stand out, he really reminded everyone how great of an actor he is wow. other than jericho of course, we also have mon confiado, romnick sarmenta, cris villanueva, and benjamin alves who stood out as well but lets not forget the women who supported this actors. karylle, ana abad santos, and angeli agbayani who wasn‚Äôt able to do much or even say much but you can feel and see everything that theyre feeling in their face, and especially their eyes, the subtleties of it all made such a huge impact. although i do wish that we were able to hear from them more, to know about their thoughts and feelings, to ser them more than as the wives of these men. especially with aurora who stuck by him and so loyal to him till the very end despite him being an unloyal douchebag. the film is so creative as well, its like watching a movie within a movie. the cinematography is so so so beautiful, theres this specific shot towards the end ‚Äîkudos to the editing as well i got goosebumps with the back and forth between quezon and aguinaldo doing their campaign and its contrast‚Äî where they were calling aguinaldo a traitor, such a good fucking shot wow. sound design and production design are undoubtedly incredible as well. i do think theres still so much to say about this film but i think this is all i got for today. i however cannot wait to see this again ‚Äî hopefully soon ‚Äî in streaming so i can pick up the parts and pieces i have missed during the first watch. tl;dr this is a good ass fucking movie and i had an incredible cinematic experience which is made even better because mon confiado and benjamin alves showed up at our screening

Would‚Äôve been a 4-5!! The color grading was unexpected for a film that tackled the Philippine Commonwealth. It felt off, almost too modern for the time period it was supposed to capture. The play on jazz tried to reflect how playful and full of tricks Quezon was, but it ended up feeling out of place rather than symbolic. Watching it with the expectation that it would have the same weight or sharpness as Goyo or General Luna, medyo wala siyang dating. It lacked the same power, emotion, and impact those films delivered.The storyline and its modern approach made a few interesting points, but overall, it felt just okay. The movie leaned in on how the Philippine press was going against the idea of too much ‚Äúidealism‚Äù and not enough on honesty. The Philippines has always had issues with its government, and the film, while trying to shed light on a heroic act, missed the chance to question the systems and attitudes that kept those issues alive. Since the beginning, it‚Äôs always been about finding leaders who are good enough‚Äîbut sometimes, films like this forget that good enough isn‚Äôt the same as good.

What if politics was really just about having flair and good theatrics? Unfortunately, it‚Äôs not a what if. Through the vibrant and bold filmmaking of dir. Tarog, the film explored the conquest of Manuel Quezon with all of its grit and glory. Personally liked the use of silent film and newspaper montages into the story, as well as the surprisingly heavy plot point of journalism throught the movie. Of course, Jericho Rosales portrayed the former President Quezon remarkably. His accent and mannerism was so animated and persuasive. But Mon Confiado‚Äôs iconic performance as Aguinaldo was my favorite. Sir Mon‚Äôs character throughout the Bayaniverse is definitely cemented in Philippine cinema history.Quezon serves as a stark reminder about the disheartening loop of our so-called ‚Äúdemocracy‚Äù filled with figures vying for power using schemes and tricks. Sad to see that after 100 years, this has been our case ‚Äî being a politician all boils down to the ability to sway the public‚Äôs opinion to one‚Äôs side with the incompetency to serve.With our current issues, this is for sure an essential watch. ‚ÄòDi dapat tayo magpapaloko sa mga trapong pera at kapangyarihan lang ang habol sa gobyerno. Hindi dapat tayo mananahamik hangga‚Äôt may mananagot.

Quezon is Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs most refined film in his historical trilogy. It‚Äôs amazing to see how far his cinematography and editing has sharpened compared with the relatively low budget Heneral Luna. I hope he lives long enough to make movies about Marcos and Duterte.

Quezon is probably the most politically relevant film right now in the Philippines. It's an indictment of the so-called "trapo" system that has caused cancer to our society, and how a man like Manuel Quezon set a dangerous precedent in the political game. The film made it clear that this was the root cause. It's impressive that they managed to make this biopic without full reverence to the subject matter.This also feels like the best potential of a Filipino historical biopic. Everything feels lush, and the scope feels big, and yet it's a personal and intimate story about an event that will have prolonged effects in the future to come. The entire cast was great, especially Jericho Rosales, Mon Confiado, and Romnick Sarmenta. The ending was sublime.The film reminds us that we're long overdue for a political reform. The characters that we saw here are pretty much like the ones that we're seeing in the current political space. It is an in-your-face message, but a needed one today.

paunahang makapagyapak sa isang sinister na bodabil. a groove step to the left: independence, both word and concept, is contorted into the weapon, not the goal. a pluck of guitar strings: the men in suits in the palace don't mind that colonization is a lasting symptom, so long as they are installed as the winner. the comic takes a bow: manuel luis quezon wins the presidency, and here we are, nearly a century later, coughing blood into a handkerchief.i don't think i'll ever doubt a movie's visuals if jerrold tarog is behind the camera. the framing for the story this time was much less implicit, though it does suffer from heavy exposition at times. buti na lang it still had strong moments that show these films would sooner disappear entirely than glamorize the powerful or offer anything less than the whole picture. loses steam midway but the performances make up for it honestly! i enjoyed rosales, and im really glad they didn't waste ben alves hahaha

Planned to rewatch Heneral Luna and Goyo first before catching this so I could have a more comprehensive picture, but I couldn't find the time to do so.That being said, I'm a huge fan of the first two entries and the concept of this franchise as a whole. It's always interesting to me when films or any form of media provide a deconstruction and humanization of historical figures who are otherwise just names in our minds carved by our history lessons. With this kind of movies, our heroes become flawed men, far from the shallow descriptions in lectures and closer to the people in power currently governing our countries. With that, everything becomes much more real, and much more depressing.The campaign film gimmick is an endearing choice, and it definitely made the story livelier and much more engrossing. This film, unlike its predecessors, is less on guns and bombs and more of battles fought in the realm of politics. For Quezon, it's all just a game. And he's bloody good at it. The chapters entertainingly break down how Quezon is an early manifestation of a trapo, arrogantly moving to serve his personal interests at the expense of true service to the people.What stood out to me the most is this film's depiction of the arts (e.g. film) and the press (e.g. newspapers). It deftly demonstrated how both can be weaponized by the state to spread its propaganda, often to the point of manipulation and deception. It rings true up to now.

I have so much to say, but I truly just love it so much. The writing, execution, acting, cinematography, flow, and even color grading yes!! Sobrang wow jshdksjd this is why I love filmmaking so much. Easily 5 stars for me from start to finish.

PUTANG INA TALAGA NG SISTEMA NG PILIPINAS.noon, hanggang ngayon, ginagawang laro ang politika natin. if Luna and Goyo tried to humanize their protagonists, Quezon DE-HUMANIZES its own. the film's storytelling is non-linear, so makikita mo sa una na nanalo si Quezon as President (makikita mo na agad kung paano siya maglaro ng politika sa opening scene pa lang), then cut to Aguinaldo, stating na he's been cheated with (sa una akala mo sore loser lang si aguinaldo), then as the film progress, we sympathize with Aguinalado more than Quezon, with how the latter is manipulative and ruthless with his politics, na para bang si Quezon ang antagonist sa sarili niyang biopic. i just want to applaud the filmmakers by showing the relevant social issues of our country within a historical context, at the cost of creative liberties (tangina di ko talaga inexpect si Janolino kahit nagpakita siya sa trailer). cinematography is still superb, music just fits the whole vibe of the film, and the ACTORS/ACTRESSES putangina, walang tapon na acting sa film na toh, Jericho Rosales really embodies Quezon's swag, arrogance, and THE FUCKING ACCENT (mas malutong pa mag mura kesa kay Luna eh). the ending just gives me chills, like makikita mo talaga na concerned si Osme√±a sa kalagayan ni Quezon, but yung outburst ni Quezon made me re-think about the popular line "I am the Philippines" of Quezon. Pinapalakas ng pelikulang toh ang pag-kwestyon ko sa motibo ng iba't-ibang politiko natin ngayon, and sa tingin ko yun din naman ang gusto ipahayag ng mga filmmakers nito. anyways, such a 10/10 film.+++TAWANG-TAWA AKO DUN SA "AGUINALDO OUTLIVED ALL THREE" LINE SA CREDITS NA PARA BANG SIYA SI ENRILE.

This is by far the weakest installment in Tarog's Bayaniverse, and yet a strong start for an "experimental screenplay" by the director. Tarog isn‚Äôt just known for his heroic-themed films but also for horror works like Shake, Rattle & Roll. This time, however, it's different. He used plenty of comedic acts‚Äîso much that I almost forgot the film was a drama‚Äîwhich made it feel very unconventional and rare for him to explore such an approach.Still, he was clever and creative for going unorthodox, especially since the film revolves around sheer politics. It was dense with overwhelming dialogue. Perhaps he decided to use comedy to maintain the audience‚Äôs attentiveness, as casual moviegoers tend to have short attention spans and might easily doze off. I think it was intentional, and he just saved his cinema from a bland, dull, and boring screenplay.As for the main character, Jericho Rosales did excellently in this film. He gave an astounding performance as Quezon‚Äîenough to provoke the audience‚Äôs emotions. The mannerisms, gestures, and expressions were on point. However, I believe there might still be another actor who could‚Äôve portrayed Quezon better, as there were scenes where the acting felt somewhat unnatural, as if he was "acting an acting." On the side of fiction, Joven‚Äôs monologue never disappoints! From Luna to Goyo to Quezon, the consistency is just commendable.In addition, I really loved Tarog's uniqueness with his cinematic strategies on how he delivered the story of Quezon, plus the coin as an allegory, which is something I couldn‚Äôt explain in detail because it‚Äôs better if you watch it on the big screen. I still have a lot in mind, but I wish I were that diligent to write it all down. Anyway, this film is rated as a standalone piece, not part of the trilogy when the first two are taken into account.Overall, the film was entertaining, and the production was, as always, all-out. If you can, please watch it in cinemas. It‚Äôs worth watching.P.S. Kaya pala naging barya ang bente kasi dasurb nya???P.P.S. I just had another reason to believe it won‚Äôt end here after all these "experiments," no? üßê

Alam naman natin na may katiwalian sa pamahalaan dahil sa pamumulitika at sa pangingibabaw ng sariling interes kaysa maglingkod para sa kapakanan ng bayan. Nandiyan ang pork barrel scam noon at ang anomalya sa flood control projects ngayon. Pero bakit nga ba paulit-ulit natin sila binoboto? Sa panulat at direksiyon ni Jerrold Tarog, isa itong historical drama na tumatalakay sa buhay ng kinikilalang ikalawalang pangulo ng bansa na si Manuel Luis Quezon (Jericho Rosales) at kung paano niya nilaro ang politika. Ito ang pangatlo sa Bayaniverse ng nasabing direktor, una ang "Heneral Luna" (2015) at ikalawa ang "Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral" (2018). Sa higit na dalawang oras na takbo ng pelikula na puro diyalogo, napanatili nito ang aking interes dahil sa kakaibang direksiyon nito. Bukod sa paglalagay kay Joven Hernando (Cris Villanueva at Aaron Villaflor), nakatulong dito ang satirikong tono nito sa halip na isalaysay lamang ito nang tuwiran na makikita sa naunang dalawang pelikula. Nakatatawa na nga ang mga eksena, malalaman at maiuugnay mo pa ang mga patutsada sa kasalukuyang lagay ng politika sa bansa o sa sinumang politiko. Hindi naman kataka-taka na maitatagpi ito sa kalagayan ng pamahalaan ngayon. Ang may mas dating para sa akin ay ang gampanin ng mamamahayag sa lipunan. Ayon nga sa nalaman ko sa nadaluhang online seminar workshop para sa mga mag-aaral na mamamahayag at tagapayo ng pahayagang pampaaralan, walang obhetibo sa pamamahayag dahil may pinipiling anggulo ang tagapagbalita kaya mahalaga na maging mapanagutan at mapanuri sa isisiwalat tungo sa paghulma ng isipan at boses ng sambayanan. Kung patuloy na mas nagbibigay ng atensiyon ang mainstream na midya sa mga walang kawawaang paandar ng ilang opisyal, bago man o beterano, kaysa sa mga napapanahong isyu at adbokasiya, hindi na nakagugulat kapag nanalo ang mga ito kung sakaling tumakbo ito sa mas mataas na posisyon. Kitang-kita ito sa pelikula sa tulong ni Joven Hernando at ng kaniyang anak na si Nadya. Sumunod, kapuri-puri at kapani-paniwala ang pagganap ng mga artista. Noong una na nasa post-credit scene ng Goyo si Benjamin Alves bilang Manuel Quezon, nakakasabik dahil kamukha niya ito. Nang binago ito at naging si Jericho Rosales, nagtaka ako pero namangha pa rin kasi kamukha rin. Ngayong napanood ko sila pareho, palagay ko na tama na si Rosales ang gumanap dito. Kitang-kita sa kilos at pananalita at iisipin mo na si Quezon ang kaharap mo. Bukod dito, nag-iwan din ng impak ang ni Romnick Sarmenta bilang Sergio Osme√±a at muling pagganap ni Mon Confiado bilang Hen. Emilio Aguinaldo. Hindi rin nagpahuli sina Karylle bilang asawa ni Quezon at Angeli Bayani bilang asawa ni Aguinaldo. Panghuli, nakatulong din ang disenyong pamproduksiyon upang maging kapani-paniwala hindi lamang ang pagganap ng mga tauhan pati na rin ang tagpuan ng pelikula. Nakapag-ambag din ang musika at tunog sa tono nito. Sa kabuuan, nagkaroon ako ng kawili-wiling karanasan sa panonood nito dahil sa bagong direksiyon, kapuri-puring pagganap, kapani-paniwalang disenyong pamproduksiyon, at angkop na musika at tunog sa pang-uuyam nito. Batid nga natin na may kanser sa ating lipunan ngunit bakit ba natin pinipili pa rin ang mga trapo? Dahil sila at sila pa rin naman ang tatakbo? Dahil kilala ang apelyido nila at may malawak na makinarya sa pangangampanya kaya naniniwala tayo na sila ang magpapaunlad sa atin? O dahil naging kuntento na lamang tayo sa paniniwala na kurakot naman silang lahat? Hindi man namamalayan ng karamihan ngunit may paniniwala na may ambag ang "Heneral Luna" sa kaisipan na ayos lamang na may palamurang pinuno. Sa "Quezon", nangangamba ako na baka ang mapulot lamang ng karamihan ay iboto na lang ang kahit na sino dahil tiwali rin naman silang lahat. Hetong Bayaniverse ang magsilbing paalala sa atin na huwag makuntento sa natatamasang kaginhawaan ngayon (kung mayroon man dahil sa mga pribilehiyo) sapagkat mas karapat-dapat pa na matamo natin ang tunay na mabuting pamumuno. Huwag tayong sumamba sa mga opisyal at pumanig sa kapuwa mamamayan. Maging mapanuri at manawagan tayo sa mga pinuno dahil ito ang ating gampanin bilang kanilang nasasakupan na nakararanas ng mga pagpapasiya nila sa pamamalakad sa bansa.

Quezon es una √©pica de historia que pr√°cticamente se desenvuelve como una versi√≥n Filipina y claramente contextualizada de House of Cards. Tomando el panorama de la pol√≠tica del siglo XIX y utiliz√°ndolo para desarrollar una narrativa llena de una energ√≠a muy clara y el muy firme prop√≥sito de crear un paralelo con el sentir social contempor√°neo. Enfoc√°ndose en una lucha pol√≠tica sin cuartel y dividida en cap√≠tulos que abarcan d√©cadas de movimientos sociales filipinos. Manteniendo un tono eficiente, que le permite ser divertida en un sentido ir√≥nico y lleno de ligereza pero que no le resta seriedad a las implicaciones morales de los movimientos de sus protagonistas y sus adversarios. Llenando la narrativa entera de personajes con moralidades grises, llenos de culpas y virtudes y enfrent√°ndolos en una lucha pol√≠tica que encuentra la forma de resultar divertida y trabajar con una narrativa no lineal.

**Di ako makapili ng quote bc they were all bangers ! ! !**in this third installment of the bayaniverse, the fight for freedom and true independence from greed, corruption, and evil is no longer in the trenches, it is in our minds and hearts as filipinos. the unmasking of quezon in the intensity that they did was not how i thought this film would go (complementary). luna asked ‚Äúbayan o sarili‚Äù and quezon managed to answer ‚Äúboth‚Äù.this film was so heavy knowing we üëè are üëè still üëè frikin üëè here üëè almost a hundred years later (probably in an even worse shithole). how do you love a country full of snakes and crocodiles? (parang endemic na sila atp) and for us non-reptilians, are we complicit in the ecosystem we live in?i read a review somewhere where they said this film is nothing but a mirror and tells us what we already know. but you know what? WE FILIPINOS ARE HARD HEADED! we forgive and forget like its breathing when we often shouldn‚Äôt. so yes, we do need this mirror up every single day until we learn. we can‚Äôt also expect this film to give us a solution to our recurrent (if not perpetual) problem. it being a mirror does not reduce its value in asking us what we want to do when we don‚Äôt like what we see in the looking glass.this installment of the trilogy finally made me un-demonize aguinaldo. he‚Äôs still shit but he isn‚Äôt the devil incarnate. just as we examine the meaning of ‚Äúbayani‚Äù, we also get to examine those who have fallen from grace. mon confiado proves why he is el presidente in capturing the complexities of the man.echo truly did the role justice with the way he became a chameleon! i love the focus on this aspect of quezon especially when irl there have been 3 actors in the bayaniverse to play quezon (long live the quezon multiverse!). he will act and (literally) look different depending on his audience and what he can gain from them. this is why i don‚Äôt think we actually see the real quezon in each of these scenes. they‚Äôre all an act. its only when you piece them together where you can see a better picture of the guy. (and even then, you doubt yourself bc he has never been transparent) also, los sientos, i was confused for a few secs who was casey üò≠‚Ä¢ needed more aurora scenes ! ! ! i loved how she put him in his place often even in the most gentle of ways. ‚Ä¢ i love the repeated use of the phrase ‚Äúits not personal, its just politics‚Äù because POLITICS WILL ALWAYS BE PERSONAL! our personal values are what inform our political beliefs.‚Ä¢ now it makes sense why we have joven and had him as the pov. in a way, we are joven.‚Ä¢ if this film‚Äôs goal was to make people ask questions and feel things, they went WELL BEYOND that goal bc YES I HAVE MANY QUESTIONS AND YES I AM FEELING A LOT OF THINGS‚Ä¢ pleasant surprises for the cameos‚Ä¢ jack en poy by bullet dumas has a whole new meaning now üò≠‚Ä¢ BITCH ‚ÄúI AM THE PHILIPPINES‚Äù WTF stop making me depressed üò´üò´‚Ä¢ Serging my bias ü§©

‚ÄòQuezon‚Äô challenges its viewers to step back and critically re-examine their views on heroism, nationalism, and leadership from a moral compass by projecting a character that once stood at the cusp of burgeoning pressure for independence by opposing Filipino revolutionary and American imperialist fronts. Although the film still embodies the overarching themes of its predecessors, Quezon‚Äôs most notable feature was finally cementing Joven into the ‚Äúbayaniverse‚Äù (or more accurately, the ‚ÄúAguinaldo Trilogy‚Äù) not just as a mere spectator or narrator, but as a key and active player in Tarrog‚Äôs world ‚Äî a powerful symbol resembling the Filipinos‚Äô evolving compromises and complicity amid the turbulent socio-political landscape of the time.An essential spin on a familiar trope, Quezon is by far the most comprehensive de-construction of ‚Äúwhat makes a hero‚Äù in Tarrog‚Äôs roster of historical epics. A must watch for the incredible performances, especially from Echo and Mon.
