Waited for this movie for maybe 8 years and I was not left disappointed. This is the historical drama I was waiting for and the depiction I never knew I wanted. This trilogy has proven and show that our heroes weren't perfect people. They've done bad things, got their hands dirty, and burned bridges but they were also instrumental in building our nation. Sometimes, these heroes are also reflective of our nation and who we can be. The Philippines has its share of problems but it's still a beautiful country and has the potential to be something great. We might be just as imperfect as the heroes in Jerrold Tarog's trilogy were but just like them, we still have the capability to bring the country somewhere great. I hope that one day, we bring this country away from where it is right now and beat the corruption that plagues it.Besides that important lesson and theme I got from the movie, I think the movie is an amazing piece of Philippine cinema from its acting to the cinematography to the editing. It's truly amazing. There were a few creative choices that I feel like could've been edited or shot better but I still think this movie is a masterpiece just like the other two in the trilogy.

Quezon isn‚Äôt perfect, but it‚Äôs a meaningful addition to Filipino cinema‚Äôs take on its heroes. It‚Äôll appeal most to viewers who like their history w/ nuance & aren‚Äôt looking for a straightforward hero-story.It doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing Quezon‚Äôs contradictions: idealism vs self-interest, leadership vs authoritarian streaks. The film invites reflection rather than worship.Heneral Luna started the fire. Goyo showed the cost. Quezon‚Äôs the anti hero master stroke that perfectly wraps up the Bayaniverse trilogy. One small gripe: Iain Glen does his best as Leonard Wood, but the accent keeps playing hide & seek w/ the dialogue. He‚Äôs commanding, sure, but his Scottish accent slips through just enough to break the illusion. For a film committed to period accuracy, it‚Äôs funny how the one thing they didn‚Äôt localize was his vowels. Maybe next time, just cast an American & spare Glen the vocal gymnastics.

ika nga ni joven, wala namang masama sa kompromiso, ngunit para kanino? while the film strives to capture the weight and moral complexity of quezon‚Äôs leadership, it lacks the firm historical backbone needed to fully ground its narrative. i wished the film had delved deeper into the implications of the american occupation and quezon‚Äôs nuanced role within it. jericho rosales really sounded like a politician who takes on charisma and commanding presence to gain people's trust. well, mon confiado is mon confiado. tsaka, di na kailangan yung part ni cong.nevertheless, films like this will always remain vital. they invite us to analyze and confront historical narratives being presented to us. in an era when political figures are often portrayed as heroes of their time, this film serves as a reminder of our responsibility to discern whether their legacies truly served the people‚Äôs best interests.

I have nitpicks with this that I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a good thing or a bad thing:1. The execution of this was disorienting at first. Because all of a sudden it was theatrical, vaudeville, and full-on period. But when the plot thickens, it suddenly makes sense ‚Äî On how the politics at the time (let‚Äôs face it, until today), is just one big show and performance at stake of actual lives.2. The timejumps was a bit confusing at first. When it jumped from film to life and back out again with no immediately understandable visual cues, it was snapping me out of the world. But again, when the plot thickens, you kinda get the point. This may be my personal issue, but it took me sometime to get to that point.And my most major thing with this:I BOTH LOVE AND HATE, I AM BOTH AMAZED AND DISAPPOINTED, ALL AT THE SAME TIME - On how this reflects to until today. This was basically the birth of a trapo. It says so in the film that this was the game of politics, showcased at large on how it was played, and how it evolved into the game of today. What I hate most is that the main messaging of political idolatry is still a rampant and relevant message that still needs to be relayed to today. And mind you, this was more or less than 80 years ago. How far we‚Äôve gotten yet how slow our progress be.Also, I watched this one alone. And I kinda regret that, which is a RARE reaction I get from watching a film (because I love watching films alone). But this is a discussion me and my friends had before that we may dive deeper into after this film: ‚ÄúWas the Philippines premature to be independent before? Should we have taken more time to be colonized?‚Äù. No ill-intent in that question, it is purely a curious question. And one that was once again, sparked by this film.A thinktank, a conversation-igniter, which is how historical films should be. Especially in a country like the Philippines.

an illuminating way to end the trilogy!!!from luna and goyo challenging/questioning the very idea of a hero, the idea now hangs over the viewers with the cunning quezon like a full teacher-student-application cycle. they truly couldnt have problematized a character more positioned inconspicuously than quezon because he‚Äôs a walking contradiction of the nationalista party. the party name itself lends him the suspicion, honestly (and as it should be for everyone in a political party). but it‚Äôs really his pork barrel, patronage, and gross abuse of power all the more delayed ph independence.i loved studying quezon (admittedly more than rizal) back then and i love now that the film enjoys a layer of experimentation and harkens back to current events. again, quezon was the perfect final man for the trilogy because we see the semblances of his political manipulation and we still feel the context of colonial forces‚Äô strong hold upon us, it‚Äôs just wildly more discreet. the film was a transgression in both content and form, which is strikingly reflexive of how history (insofar as it‚Äôs PH history involved) ebbs and flows.it‚Äôs truly a must watch and i hope this becomes more accessible for Filipinos nationwide.

Kung ang pulitika ay isang laro ng mga opisyal, bakit ang mga mamamayan ang madalas natatalo?Marami akong gustong sabihin tungkol sa Quezon ni direk Jerrold Tarog pero siguro pagpo-pokusan ko nalang ang matalinong pagkakasulat at paggamit ng mga laro sa pelikulang ito. Ang pinaka obvious ay ang Chess, kung saan ang naglalaban ay ang panig ni Quezon para sa puti, at si Osme√±a naman ang sa itim. Isa sa mga paborito kong scene yung nasa isang malaking kwarto sila at tila naglalaro ng Chess para masukat kung sino ba ang mas ma-impluwensiya sa kanila. Sa huli, na checkmate si Osme√±a. Talo siya.Pangalawa naman ay ang tila paglalaro nila ng Snakes and Ladders. Maraming scene ang nagaakyat-baba ang mga karakter sa hagdan, madalas ay kapag nabibigo silang makuha ang nais nila, galit silang bumababa, parang natuklaw ng ahas‚Äî tingin nila, ipinagkanulo sila ng panahon o ng mga kasamahan. Lahat gustong umakyat ng hagdan, lahat gustong manalo.Huli ang poker. Kanya-kanyang laro ng kani-kanilang mga baraha. Kung sino ang may mas maaalam na baho ng kalaban, siya ang panalo. Sa scene kung saan nagtatalumpati ang mga kandidato, para silang nagpo-poker. Panalo ang kung sinumang may hawak ng pinakamagandang baraha. O hindi kaya, kung sino ang pinakamarunong mang-bluff. Sa huli, kahit hawak ni Miong ang isang magandang alas, pinili niyang hindi ito gamitin. Fold.Sa paglalaro nila ng pulitika, tagasubaybay tayo tulad ni Joven. Mahirap tantsahin kung kanino tayo papanig. Sila-sila rin lang naman ang naglalaro. Hanggang ngayon, tau-tauhan lamang tayo sa bulok na laro ng pulitika. Walang tunay na demokrasya. This is such a powerful film to be shown in our current time. The potryal of the way politics worked in the past is an almost complete reflection to the present. I love the fact that Quezon isn't shown as a protagonist that you wanted to cheer for all through out. It captures the very idea of politics itself, its not black or white, it is a game in which in order to get what you want, you have to do some underhanded tactics. Quezon himself knew how to play the game. Lets talk about, Aguinaldo next, in this film he is tired and beaten down, he was out of his depth in challenging Quezon. Aguinaldo was characterized in which a part of you will feel sympathy for him, but makes you aware that everything that led to his downfall was through his actions. Overall, the other Characters are well acted and very on the point. As a long time history nerd, I would say this is a 10/10 film.

On the critique that Quezon (the film) is vague in its idea of independence:That's exactly part of MLQ's politics: the wielding of power is being the origin or source of a great idea, the new republic as a goal only Cassey can achieve. That is how political campaigns are inspired. That's how devotion to political figures has taken its root. Whatever concept of freedom there is should appear like it's going to come directly from the politician. Independence being perceived as food conveys the idea that it's constantly asked, not fought for, by the masses that wait for 'ayuda' rather than the affirmation of their capacity to hold freedom in their hands. And why is 'independence' or 'new republic' mentioned in the film like a byword? It's because Quezon wears it like a badge. But it serves a more important purpose: It floats as a concept that's never really understood. It remains to be a hollow idea associated with patriotism. So it continues to be talked about because it's never truly experienced. Valid pa rin ang tanong na "What is a new republic?" hanggang ngayon. So it's odd to expect the film to define independence for us when what it does is actually more essential.We define it. I trust that we know how to.

Sabi ni Cinemaster Nadz Amata:Simply an amazing film to end Tarog‚Äôs Bayani Trilogy. Quezon harnessed the strengths of its predecessors Heneral Luna and Goyo, producing a film with strong storytelling, great actors, and awesome cinematography. Although he did not physically look like the mestizo Casey, Jericho Rosales delivered an enigmatic performance well-deserving of acting awards. But among its merits, perhaps my favorite thing about Quezon is its pointed delivery of political critique not only towards the current administration but to the long history of corrupted, patronizing, and self-serving Philippine politics.I know for sure that it is not only me who feared that Quezon would end up sanitizing the former president‚Äôs image, as films about politicians and heroes tended to do so. But alas, Quezon was not usual biopic that mythologized the man ‚Äî instead, it demystified him, reintroducing the former President that plastered his and his wife‚Äôs name all over his home province and the biggest city in Metro Manila. It was able to effectively deliver Manuel Luis Quezon as the cunning politician, borderline dictator that he is.Alongside his intelligent spiels and populist rhetoric, the film revealed the unapologetic and manipulative character of the 2nd President of the Philippine Republic ‚Äî the man who laid the formula of political maneuvering for the politicians and would-be presidents after him, proving Alfred McCoy‚Äôs view that Quezon‚Äôs Commonwealth paved the way for Philippine authoritarianism.I do hope that Tarog continues to develop new historical fiction films in the future. More than ever, we need more films that tackle and communicate our history in interesting ways that provoke the audience to revisit our past and reexamine our stances on our ‚Äògreat‚Äô men.

Another great interpretation of MLQ‚Äôs political life. It has a jumpy storyline, jumping from different timelines in Quezon‚Äôs life. Imo it‚Äôs not up to par with its prior bayaniverse movies (Heneral Luna goat), but the cinematography, theatrics, and plot delivery are surely Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs forte. The acting is also soooo good, Jericho nailed that accent
Hindi na ata talaga bago ang ang pagiging ganid sa kapangyarihan at pagiging kurakot ng mga pulitiko sa Pilipinas. Ika nga ay one politician after another ‚Äî and nothing has changed.

What a way to close out the Bayaniverse trilogy. From the ultraviolent chaos of Heneral Luna, to the somber introspection of Goyo, Quezon rounds things off as a psychological thriller-slash-political comedy-slash-drama that‚Äôs as ambitious as it is sharp.What I‚Äôve always admired about Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs depiction of these historical figures is how human they are. There are no pure heroes here‚Äîonly flawed men navigating ambition, ego, and nationhood. Quezon, played brilliantly by Jericho Rosales, is a political gamemaster: part statesman, part showman, and wholly cunning. I love that the film doesn‚Äôt dwell on textbook achievements, but rather on the intricate dance of manipulation, charm, and power that defined his leadership.Like the best Filipino historical films of recent memory, Quezon reflects its own era back at us‚Äîthe politics of then echoing the politics of now, for better or worse.And while it‚Äôs billed as the end of the Bayaniverse, I hope this isn‚Äôt an exclamation point, but a comma‚Äîespecially after that tantalizing post-credits tease.

Here we begin with a shapeshifting exploiter on one hand and a docile, equally ambitious prowler on the other, juggled and brandished to trade barbs and heave vitriol at each other, both would later dismiss as mere politics to justify a much-needed partnership, then finding a common enemy in a chagrined former revolutionary leader and president. The ping-pong exchange of politicking and smear campaigns is its most coruscating part‚Äîelectrifying to me, actually‚Äîa protracted look at our current politics' saddening origin. Quezon‚Äînow that there is no need for battle pieces, as that is not Tarog's turf‚Äîis the most polished in the entire trilogy, only slightly tarnished by its caricature bits and overreliance on fictional characters. The decision to minimize young Joven's speaking lines saves the entire cast's immaculate efforts from futility.

It was so fascinating to see the things I've learned in history books be dramatized in film.What a time to be alive to witness a trilogy of films that tells a story of heroes, but also deconstruct them, showcase them as three-dimensional characters, as people and not as good guys up on pedestals.The change of tone from the seriousness and war setting of Heneral Luna and Goyo to the more modern setting of Quezon threw me off, but also had me engaged. Especially with the way they make a meta-commentary of the power of film and media to portray these stories. Jericho Rosales is wonderful to see on screen as MLQ, and Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio Osme√±a showed a fun dynamic--almost like a romantic couple--between Quezon and Osme√±a.The non-linear storytelling was also a change that I had to adjust after re-watching the first two in preparation for this. Thankfully, there are title cards and chapters that serve as good guide posts for the pacing of the story.Speaking of story, as this film spanned a longer timeframe compared to the two, it's written to showcase more vignette-type and montage-style of events rather than the more straightforward storytelling in Luna and Goyo. While it's not a bad thing, it can be difficult to keep track of while watching. Also, pacing is an issue as some parts dragged and other moments could've used more time to absorb its messaging.The showcase of Quezon's con artistry and showcasing him as a chameleon is done very well. This movie was really a battle of wits instead of arms--and it truly showcased the Filipino political culture.The production and set design were done incredibly well. A lot of effort was put to make this a period piece. While some seams and cracks can be seen here-and-there, those can be mostly ignored and do not hinder my enjoyment of the film. There isn't that much bloodshed and prosthetic wounds to be seen here, but more on CG buildings, vehicles, and recreation of period appropriate settings and props.---SPOILER THOUGHTS---I think they could've had a Mabini scene somewhere as having Aguinaldo, Joven, Rusca, and Janolino weren't enough connective tissue for me to fully connect this movie with the previous two.The Alerta storyline and Nadia filmmaking storyline could've been tighter as these were the parts that dragged the most. Though I do appreciate having this fictional plot point to give commentary on the importance of film, media, journalism, and media literacy--I do think this could be polished more and make less preachy. In the previous films, I didn't feel like I was being banged with the head with all of its messaging because of how beautiful the writing is and how its themes weave together with its characters. In here, that magic was kinda muddled a bit. But there were still some scenes and lines that made such a good impact on me.His abrupt death and shouting into the abyss, left me dissatisfied to be honest. Both Luna and Goyo's death were shown on-screen while here, it's just implied and presented to us through text. I would've loved to see him actually die in his sleep or something or maybe have Osme√±a receive the news and take his place and then have the epilogue of the movie there.Lastly, all three films had some sort of subplot of the protagonist having some sort of affair. I think Aurora Quezon was underutilized here. Luna's affair with Isabel makes sense as the character was an amalgamation of various women in Luna's life. Goyo's love affairs with Felicidad and Dolores were the most poetic and beautifully done juxtaposed with the sacrifices of war. Quezon's love for Aurora and the affair with Ana Ricardo was so tense but not as strong as I would like it to be as both women were more plot device than actual characters.---END OF SPOILER THOUGHTS---Quezon is a great film and I am thankful to have watched it on the big screen. I think it is the weakest of the trilogy, but it still has its redeeming qualities. It can be frustrating in a negative sense with some of the complaints I have, but this film and the entire Bayani-verse trilogy of movies are frustrating in the positive sense--as ALL three were well-written to present themes, lessons, and events that are still relevant to this day. These films show history but as so well-crafted to mirror the political issues we have at present.I don't want this to be the last film. I do hope there are more stories to tell and themes to explore in our history.

I really enjoyed this movie! Jericho Rosales doesn't really look like Quezon, I was really hesitant at his casting first especially as the original Quezon TJ Trinidad (and even the younger Quezon Benjamin Alves as well as Apolinario Mabini actor from previous Bayaniverse films Epy Quizon) looks more similar to the real Quezon, but Jericho did really make up for his acting. I love how the political tactics and intrigue are made with comedic timing, keeping audiences interested in the screen. I thought Mon Confiado was really perfect as Quezon and Iain Glen's special appearance as Governor General Leonard Wood was fantastic. I thought Karylle's Aurora Quezon doesn't have much to do in the movie, but I was really impressed with her acting especially when she realized Quezon's first "wife" was in the same event as her and Quezon.The movie seems to be based strongly on facts, but I couldn't find from my research information about this so called first "wife" of Quezon before Aurora. But I do think she was used very well in the plot of this movie. The fictional characters Joven Hernando and his daughter Nadia are well used in this movie as well. They are intended to represent the audiences (especially Filipino audiences as their Filipino history shown in this movie is still relevant today). Overall a great third movie in Jerrold Tarrog's Bayaniverse movie films (along with 2015's Heneral Luna and 2018's Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral).

the writing, visual production, and sound design were so, so sharp; it was impossible to be bored, even for a film that centered around talking politicians. ang galing! maybe not my favorite out of the three in the bayaniverse, but i do believe it to be the most relevant as its closest to our present reality today. it very effectively punctures our lack of regard for some of the earliest developments of our current republic. it then became a great illustration of how the governance and systems we face today doesn‚Äôt fall far from the tree (unfortunately). in that sense, the film is a lot less emotionally moving compared to its counterparts in the trilogy. instead, it was moreso unsettling: and maybe that‚Äôs the point!! history is not merely the study of the past, but it is also how the present came to be and continues to evolve as we speak. moreover, heroes are but names we give to very much real people with a human capacity for malice and fault. much credit to jerrold tarog for the bayaniverse trilogy. had it not been for general luna, i‚Äôd not have gone on history deep dives in my free time (because unfortunately the last time we had proper philippine history as a class was in grade 6). we‚Äôre often apprehensive to approach history as the mere thought of the many big names and events intimidate us ‚Äî especially when we think that history is just dead people and shit that went down years ago. but what if we just don‚Äôt realize that history is actually, very much as well, the now? quezon (2025) is a great ender to the trilogy because it cements such idea. it‚Äôs chilling to think about how time has passed and how much has stayed the same. thinking about it all has made me unsettled (which, again, i think is the point).

a detail that im fixated on about this movie is quezon‚Äôs use of the word ‚Äúindependence‚Äù. he uses the idea of it as a bluff and it‚Äôs almost like a tell in his strategy for the game that people somehow fall for time and time again. it almost becomes a kind of semantic satiation, with the amount of times he promises it, it starts losing its meaning ‚Äìsaid meaning already being completely misunderstood, or at least, understood without the weight and depths and nuances of it.another side of his promise for independence of the philippines is how the film rounds the statement up by the end with quezon screaming ‚Äúi am the philippines‚Äù ‚Äìthe implication of his life‚Äôs work only being dedicated to a kind of independence for Himself and not for the country‚Ä¶.manjesus christ the amount of times i wanted to pull my hair out at anytime i am reminded this shit is still happening Right Now watching this film feels like being shot 47498 timespota ang ganda nakakagalitfjfjfalso: quezon calling osme√±a mi querido and osme√±a replying with barely contained lust‚Ä¶.jerrold tarog WILL have historical yaoi in every movie in the bayaniverse

marami ang politiko, ngunit kakaunti lamang ang lingkod bayan.there are numerous reasons in which individuals desire to enter politics, but not everyone is really a public servant. you have to possess tremendous power to influence in order to become such a powerful individual. my opinion is that many who become so influential are not exercising this power for good governance, rather for personal interests. this thinking can bring about patronage politics, corruption, and insensitivity to the needs of the people(which is actually happening rn).It's sad to see people put personal interest ahead of the common good.this film sheds some light on this aspect by depicting the shrewd personality of Manuel Quezon, our first president commonwealth president(that‚Äôs why andaming palang proposed constitution, and yung transition about tydings-mcduffie act hindi tinuro sa‚Äômin kung what was the real story behind those numerous revisions and amendments). It depicts how his calculated and shrewd politics influenced the country's history, but at the same time points out the ambiguity between heroism and manipulation. the film instigates us to challenge our understanding of historical icons and what it actually means to be a hero. It gives us inspiration to think critically on leadership and governance, and to aim for a system where power is utilized for the common good, not for a chosen few. while reflecting on Quezon's legacy, we are reminded that genuine public servants are those who put the greater good first, not personal interests.

Quezon, in terms of storytelling, is different from the approach of Heneral Luna and Goyo. Not that the previous films were set during the war for independence and Quezon was more about words, but Tarog‚Äôs treatment here was somewhat different.What I appreciate about this new approach is its new perspective. In this film, we see Quezon through the lens of Nadia‚Äôs works, portrayed as both a hero and a shrewd politician ‚Äî a duality reflected by the people around him like Joven, who seem like spectators to his life. The storytelling feels more playful yet sharp, much like the mind games shown in the film, which perfectly capture his wit and sly character. I also liked the use of the title card inspired by the silent era in the sequence that introduces Quezon ‚Äî a clever way to bridge the past and the present.The scenes of love-hate tension between him and Osme√±a, his attempts to outsmart Leonard Wood, and his feud with Aguinaldo make us, as viewers, feel like spectators in this grand game of politics. Despite the seriousness of the subject, the humor and comedic tone remain, giving the film a lighter touch ‚Äî something I truly appreciate. It also highlights the absurdity of politics, showing how politicians can sometimes be clowns themselves. Quezon is definitely a film worth watching in cinemas. I also appreciate its cinematography and sound design, which add so much to the overall narrative.

Quezon is less about defining a hero and more about what a hero isn't. With no guns and battles this time, Tarog's final film in the trilogy relied on a well-written screenplay and a brilliant direction and editing. This felt polished and grand.Jericho Rosales plays Quezon masterfully with his unmatched charisma and mischievous persona. Every department of this production brought their A-game (except the makeup which was at times distracting). The writing here is particularly good, in my opinion the best of the trilogy.Quite an experience going home from the cinema in a motorcycle, seeing his name in every corner of every street in this city named after him. His legacy indeed lived on. Scary to think that the unprincipled legacy of the people running this country today might live on too just like his.

Quezon is not your typical biopic. It doesn‚Äôt simply glorify the titular figure, nor does it aim to reduce him to a villain. It‚Äôs a sharp, unsettling mirror. The cinematography is well-executed, every shot deliberate and meaningful. I loved how the film plays with style: the silent movie and noir sequences are such clever touches. There‚Äôs a bit of camp, even excess, but it works. Politics has always been a performance in the Philippines anyway, and this film leans right into that.It‚Äôs not afraid to show Quezon as both idealist and egotist, leader and manipulator. The movie calls out how he perfected the art of political spectacle, something we‚Äôre still drowning in today. At times, it gets too caught up in that same spectacle, focusing on power plays more than the people affected by them, but maybe that‚Äôs part of the point.What stings most is how familiar it all feels. The greed, the posturing, the foreign meddling: it‚Äôs the same game, just with new players. Quezon isn‚Äôt perfect, but it‚Äôs sharp, stylish, and painfully relevant. It doesn‚Äôt just revisit history; it forces us to realize we‚Äôve never really left it.(P.S. Give Jericho Rosales his well-deserved FAMAS now!! that perforamance was spectacular!!)
BANAL-BANALAN KANG BURAT KA

Nakakatuwang isipin na kahit medyo natagalan bago nasundan at dumaan sa maraming hamon, ngayon ay mapapanood na rin natin ang ‚Äúfinal installment‚Äù ng Bayaniverse. This time, nakatutok ang pelikula kay Manuel L. Quezon, upang ipakita sa mga Pilipino kung ano nga ba ang tunay na kahulugan ng pagiging bayani. So, was it worth the wait?One thing‚Äôs very clear: this movie is made with passion and love. Every aspect, production design, costume, music, sound design, acting, and screenplay, everything feels precise and deliberate. Walang sayang. Busog ang mata mo, at napakasarap sa pandinig ng bawat linya at tugtugin.I also appreciate that the film didn‚Äôt contradict anything from the previous installments. There‚Äôs no unnecessary retcon, and even smaller roles were reprised by the same actors (except for Joross Gamboa as Eduardo Rusca, previously played by Archie Alemania). Hindi ko nga agad napansin na siya pala iyon until I checked online, still, I appreciate his inclusion.What leaves me conflicted, however, is how the narrative perspective centers on Joven. He‚Äôs a good character, pero minsan nawawala ang connection natin kay Quezon. Unlike the first two films where we clearly see the world through the minds of Luna and Goyo, dito parang ikinukuwento lang sa atin ang nararamdaman ni Quezon. That sometimes creates a bit of emotional distance. I get that the film wants to show that our heroes are just as flawed and human as we are, and I love that message, but I wish we could‚Äôve seen more of Quezon‚Äôs inner struggle.The non-linear structure works surprisingly well. Kahit medyo gimmicky, it adds flavor to the storytelling, especially since we already know where the story is headed.Jericho Rosales delivers a powerful and charismatic performance as Quezon. Mon Confiado also brings his A-game, while Cris Villanueva, Arron Villaflor, and Rominick Sarmenta shine in their respective roles. For Iain Glen, I honestly feel another actor could‚Äôve played the part, but it‚Äôs still commendable that they brought in a respected Hollywood actor for the role.Overall, Quezon is a strong and passionate film. It may be overly ambitious at times, occasionally losing sight of its identity, but its heart is in the right place. The message remains powerful: kahit ilang taon na ang lumipas, tila hindi pa rin nagbabago ang mga Pilipino.And if ever this isn‚Äôt truly ‚Äúthe end,‚Äù I hope we still get to see more stories from the Bayaniverse, especially with that mid-credit scene tease.

It was a good film, though I'm still trying to understand why some consider it to be the weak link in the Bayaniverse trilogy. It's actually a wonderful movie. Confiado's delivery was excellent, it even brought me to tears because you could truly feel how he fought back against political corruption in the Philippines. I'm not just talking about the character, but this actually reflects our society today and how we struggle and fight against corrupt politicians. It's also great‚Ä¶

Independence: Good enough to eat.127 years of Philippine independence, but are we truly free? Do our statesmen really know how to operate this country with 'freedom' in their hands? Do we even deserve this freedom? Will we ever learn?‚ÄãThis is what Quezon leaves you with. This movie is enjoyable and, as always, provoking.‚ÄãIt brings to mind that known quote from him: "I'd rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by Americans." Hearing that again, with what's happening to our country, made me laugh. I like how Tarog thinks, always aiming for relevance by connecting his historical movies to what's happening right now.‚ÄãAs someone who didn't know much about Quezon, I learned a lot and was reminded of the things he did. But it's also a movie about politics. We are introduced to their games, how they operated, and how they think. Today, it might seem obvious. But to think that this has been happening long before our independence has me worried. I was sitting in the cinema literally not knowing exactly how I feel, other than discomfort.‚ÄãTechnically, I appreciated the writing. Despite being dialogue-heavy, the lines are witty and written with a style similar to the Bayaniverse. I also like the aesthetic; it reminds me of Wes Anderson (very subtle) and the likes with its use of symmetry, colors, and scores.‚ÄãUltimately, we are shown the humane side of our celebrated heroes. While we appreciate what they've done for our country, we should not be blind to consider them human‚Äînot idols, not kings, not gods.‚ÄãMaraming magagandang salita sa pelikula, pero siguro ang mainam na panapos ay:Maraming politiko, kakaunti ang lingkod-bayan.

‚ÄúBody and soul?‚ÄùOur answer to an Armando Ianucci political satire. Dare I say well shot, exquisitely paced, with nail-biting dialogue that speaks from a century ago to our time. Quezon is a political animal that knew no satisfaction but perhaps was a mere reflection of the period where America (his puppet masters) were too first learning the prizes of Empire. Rosales gives perhaps his defining performance in this stage of his career. Just verve and energy radiating off the screen! Like any of history‚Äôs narcissists, it was a downfall well portrayed and a rise to power that echoes DiCaprio‚Äôs Jordan Belfort. (Where to mention the crispness of a Scorsese film‚Äôs editing is also possibly a clear inspiration for this film). Mon Confiado‚Äôs Aguinaldo was humanized well away from the El Presidente‚Äôs mythic stature. The birth of patronage politics and its attacks on journalism and truth was impeccably presented. Never to the point of celebrating it but dangles its dangers for people to discover and hopefully decry. 4/5

I think this one might be the Bayaniverse trilogy's "Before Midnight." Comparing this to Goyo and Heneral Luna, this one is not making you root for our main character but simply interested to see his downfall. (3/3 bayaniverse) MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS (but then again, this is our history lol)key takeaways:- si sergio osme√±a pala ang OG backburner- ang quezon ay sinaunang friends to enemies to lovers and again trope - naabutan pa pala ng nanay at tatay ko si aguinaldo wth :-)on a more serious note:- my bayaniverse ranking as of now is: quezon, goyo, luna. i liked goyo better than luna because of its more introspective direction and for me, was a better deconstruction of our "heroes". i liked quezon better than goyo because of its fresh direction and it's a different kind of war, political mind games.- regarding the fresh direction, i was so fond of the grand budapest-esque style in the initial parts of the movie and how it kind of pulled a moulin rouge route (a story within a story).- tbh, mentally nasuka ako after finishing the film. the realization that before marcos sr., we had quezon :---) parang as if sa kanya nagmula ang formula ng pagiging trapo: more of a showman, less of a public servant. - also, as much as aguinaldo was villainized in the first film, in here, he was portrayed as some sort of "lesser evil"- lastly, the highlight of it all and what i was waiting for ever since i learned about it in KAS 1, as much as quezon played us, he, too, is just a piece from a much bigger game being played by the US. that despite it all, have we truly been independent from them?

Director Jerrod Tarog delivers another masterpiece in the Bayaniverse with a showcase in filmmaking excellence in acting, cinematography, editing, production and costume design. I was initially thrown off by Jericho Rosales and Romnick Sarmienta's accents (never bothered to check if that's how Quezon and Osmena sounded in real life) but they're 2 of today's best actors that I eventually appreciated how they fully embodied their respective roles. Ditto Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, Karylle as Do√±a Aurora, JC Santos as Roxas, and even Cris Villanueva as fictional character journalist Joven Hernando. It was also nice to see Iain Glen (Jorah Mormont in Game of Thrones) play Governor-General Wood. Quezon's bantering/arguments with both Osmena and Wood were quite amusing/entertaining. Also commend the shift in tone which was like a breath of fresh air in telling a Pinoy historical drama (sort of reminded me of Mike de Leon's 'Bayaning 3rd World' which also starred Villanueva). But if I were to nitpick, I'd note that if Luna and del Pilar were humanized in their respective biographical war dramas, Quezon was villainized here as the idealistic patriot fighting for Philippine independence turned scheming, power hungry politician. Yes, this film showed that the country has been (prodominantly) run by politicians, not public servants.

‚ÄúMasyadong maraming politiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan.‚Äù What a fun watch. The most notable thing about this trilogy is how many times I‚Äôve admittedly said ‚ÄúHindi ko alam na ganito pala sila‚Ä¶‚Äù which makes the storytelling even more compelling. I am in pure awe of TBA‚Äôs works. Mahusay kayo!

Love Jericho Rosales and Mon Confiado in this, and I particularly like what the film has to say about (the origins of) patronage politics and strongman politics in the Philippines and their intertwined history with colonialism, and when the film is actively trying to make us think what constitutes heroism (is a strongman un-photographed in his weaker moments the same strongman captured on magazine covers?). But lord, also the very definition of maingay, chicharon, bungangera. Exposition as dialogue, and not even doing the subtlest job at hiding it. Hate it when Rody just goes ahead and shoves everything down our throats like he's breeding geese for foie gras (sorry, Rody); counterpoint: the PETA play Under My Skin, for instance. At some point, I was like, get a move on, we've been saying the same exact thing over and over again for like 10 minutes already. And the whole watching the daughter's work in the empty cinema device just so we can have the flashback scenes--ugh.

YOU CAN‚ÄôT LOSE WITH QUEZONAfter three watches, I can safely say one thing: I have so many thoughts about the Quezon movie, and yet so little words to convey it in. I wrote so many passages down in my notebooks. All of them half-finished or just me arguing with myself trying to make sense of what I was feeling. I‚Äôll try my best to write them here.The Bayaniverse, one of my favorite Filipino movie series, has finally come to a close with (arguably) one of their best movies yet. Quezon veers away from the usual historical biopic formula and moves into the territory of being a social commentary.Instead of the ‚Äúevent A happened, so event B follows‚Äù format, Quezon asks us to sit with discomfort. Rather than simply glorifying its subject, the movie presents a national hero who reflects the leaders we have now. A visionary who fought for Filipino independence, yet, a calculating statesman who mastered the performance of politics. Charming when needed, ruthless when required, and deeply aware of optics.I see the movie as something that doesn‚Äôt necessarily paint Quezon in a necessarily evil nor corrupt light, but as a pragmatic who knew that idealism alone could not dismantle a colonial-imperialism system built on inequality. That pragmatism, however, is exactly what built the foundations of our current political structure.What does that say about our national heroes? What does that say about the kinds of people we choose to enshrine and remember? Most importantly, what does that say about us?The Quezon we see in the movie is not simply Quezon‚Äìhe‚Äôs also the collective psyche of the nation that produced him and the time that he lived in. He lived under an imperialist, racist U.S. government! As the movie perfectly states, ‚ÄúQuezon may not have made the game, but he sure did play it.‚ÄùI think Quezon challenges the comfort that we have in hero worship. It dares us to look at power. Not as a moral test or a path to self-actualization, but as a mirror to who we are as a nation going through growing pains. Is it worth acknowledging that building a road to greatness often comes with destroying whatever comes ahead?The real message of the Bayaniverse, in my opinion, is that the nation was not built by perfect saints. It was also built by people who have the tendency to be selfish, flawed, ambitious, and painfully human. The series tells us that our understanding of heroism must mature as we continue to mature as a nation.On a more personal note, I will never forget the feeling of watching it on the big screen. What an amazing movie. The dialogue is witty, suspenseful, and human. Another thing I love about it is the casting. Everyone is so perfect! I knew that Jericho Rosales was a good actor, but he was PHENOMENAL as MLQ! I didn‚Äôt expect it at all.The music and cinematography are top-notch too. What a movie! I‚Äôd love to be part of something like this one day.I‚Äôve been told that I have the tendency to go insane about the things I love. I‚Äôm not a movie person, but I‚Äôd love to go to the theater to watch it again, but that‚Äôd require me to open my commissions (and so, I‚Äôm opening my commissions to watch it again).

It is undeniable that Quezon was depicted as a power-hungry egoistical person in this film. If you think about it, the film unfolds based on the journalist‚Äôs perspective. Both on different sides of the coin, but then again, it was the same coin.. talagang morality bends if ikaw ang nakikinabang. Every scene felt like a chess move, a power move even. The Quezon-Osme√±a dynamic is so compelling to watch, I am definitely moved.Now about the movie, the cinematography is noticeably visibly great. Even the details tell a story and are so hard not to miss.. the color grade, the camera movement, the aesthetics, and the pacing, all on point !!! Jerrold Tarog showed me a fresh new perspective that makes me want to go down the rabbit hole and watch all his films. hehe I think I just fell in love with history? Quezon is definitely a film worth watching, I am even considering rewatching it now.
toxic doomed yaoi aside, i really do love how they made this. SS classes taught us on wrong lies‚Ä¶ Glad to see and recognize that ever since may mga kurakot sa gubyerno natin.

Quezon feels like a well-crafted film that Jerrold Tarog put a lot of effort into, both in writing and directing. Rosales‚Äôs performance as the lead really stands out and carries the movie. Visually, it‚Äôs a treat with a unique old-school style and great production design that captures the early 1900s vibe perfectly.The story also creates a good amount of intrigue, even if some parts aren‚Äôt perfectly executed. Despite its flaws, it‚Äôs an interesting watch because of its strong visuals and engaging narrative. Overall, Quezon is a solid film that shows real craftsmanship and is worth a watch.-flickswithmigs

painful irony of a nation striving for independence while simultaneously being undermined by internal disunity and dependence on external influence.the film offers a sharp critique of the deeply rooted filipino concept of utang na loob and exposes how it can distort the ideals of governance and public service. what once began as a moral virtue, a sign of respect and loyalty, becomes a political instrument that undermines integrity, opening the door to corruption, favoritism, and blind allegiance. it challenges viewers to reflect on how certain filipino values, while culturally meaningful, can be misused to sustain systems of power that work against true progress.at the same time, the film also confronts a difficult truth: it‚Äôs not easy to question or turn away from this cycle, especially when one is personally benefiting from those in power. comfort and convenience can blur one‚Äôs moral vision, making it hard to see the injustice hidden behind acts of generosity. it takes courage and self-awareness to break free from that dependence, to open one‚Äôs eyes and choose integrity over personal gain.

It depicts how, even long before, politicians have always been performative when it comes to their propaganda just to appear pleasing to the people. Human as we are, Filipinos as we are, we tend to be easily blinded by whatever ‚Äútruth‚Äù is presented to us, especially when it aligns with our values and principles. What struck me most (in the worst way possible) and I was genuinely flabbergasted was the case with his first wife and how he defended himself in court, saying something along the lines of, ‚ÄúDoes this face really need to rape someone?‚Äù It shows how contradicting his principles already were. You cannot fight for your country if you are struggling to be humane yourself. Quezon took Filipinos as nothing but mere tools for him to gain power. In reality, isa pa rin siyang tuta ng mga Amerikano by adhering to the same vicious practices as those American people.‚ÄúIndependence is just a word.‚Äù ‚Äì QuezonWhat really is independence? Have we truly achieved it if we remain enslaved by poor governance and corruption? After all, he said it himself that he would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by Americans. Perhaps Hobbes was right, man is selfish in nature, and he will do anything through voluntary acts if the object serves some good to himself.Is it the lesser evil for the Philippines to barely progress under Filipino rule, rather than to thrive under an American one? This isn‚Äôt to claim that the latter would be preferable, rather, it‚Äôs to assert that we deserve a government that upholds both, a competent leadership and a genuinely Filipino sense of governance.
I liked the comedic touch they added to this movie, it mirrors the current state of the Philippine politics today‚Äîa comedy show.

I entered the cinema expecting a crashcourse on history, yet I've been dished with a more nuanced understanding on our collective perception of history as a whole. The movie itself is the statement. Heneral Luna and Goyo have already fixed our expectation/s on how this will turn out: a valorous exhibit on the lives of "national heroes" that shaped Philippines as we know it; setting a preliminary idea that it will follow the same pattern about building Quezon as a major contributor of our independence. Yet, as it turns out, the movie stitches reflective points gauging on what these historical acts truly mean to us and the manner as to how these information precipitated through our minds. A magnified look into Quezon as an individual, almost overshadowing the historical context within them opens up a rare opportunity for critiqe against our national heroes. Oftentimes, we are trained to consume knowledge as quick as light, yet there is lesser existential emphasis that allow us to reject passivity in learning. I am too drowsy to add more (i will edit this soon tho), but I really enjoyed thinking about a lot of things such as the state of Philippine politics, statehood, and the lingering wonder as to what truly constitus a hero and power as recursive influence on the trajectory of history and how its viewed.

How painful it is to see this film validate one of my biggest fears about trying to make it in this country: that the only real way to succeed is by taking advantage of an unjust and cruel system, one that requires you to bring down others to bring yourself up. It‚Äôs more than just ‚Äúcrab mentality‚Äù; it‚Äôs systemic and rooted deep within, right into this country‚Äôs body and soul. So when the character of Quezon, an ambitious man who benefitted from (and allegedly originated) the country‚Äôs rotten practices, shouted ‚ÄúI am the Philippines‚Äù, I was inclined to believe him. On a side note, I‚Äôve always wanted to see more Filipino movies about politicking ‚Äî which is why the feature scripts I‚Äôve written tackle it extensively ‚Äî and so this was such a feast for me.

what's amazing about this film is how it handles pacing. everything here is just political drama. no war, no action, no theatrics. but they made it so entertaining to watch. there was no single dull moment. the direction was very clear and precise, the cinematography is very creative, the production design was stellar, and the performances are just chefs kiss especially jericho rosales as quezon. i was hesitant about his casting when it was first announced but im glad to be proved wrong. he just oozes with this charm that slowly blura the line between him and his character. and the writing supporting it and the story as a whole is amazing. the language and those political banters are quite like music. kinda like sorkin's writing style. and the music is as fun as the film itself. whats even crazier is that those two things are behind one person. and despite its greatness, this film is still far from a documentary or a biography. its a character study of a fictional character based from a real person. if you look at it as a history lesson, its not that. it greatly shows us how flawed a person is and it now our job to do the research over the real thing. the bayaniverse is a great trilogy and i hope it doesnt stop. looking forward to magsaysay.and also, just a funny thought, i cant help but give it similarities to hamilton. this whole film just gives off that loud energy of hamilton's 2nd act.

The film‚Äôs most intriguing throughline lies in Manuel Quezon‚Äôs (Jericho Rosales) exchanges with Joven Hernando (Arron Villaflor as the young journalist, Cris Villanueva as the older one). Joven, who once idolized Quezon, becomes his conscience and later his accuser, returning a coin once given to him as a symbol of principle. Their relationship encapsulates writer-director Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs grand question: can integrity survive intimacy with power? It‚Äôs through Joven‚Äôs eyes that we watch the statesman‚Äôs transformation into strongman, his lofty rhetoric curdling into patronage politics. When Quezon shuts down Joven‚Äôs newspaper for publishing an expos√©, the betrayal stings not only as political allegory but as personal tragedy‚Äîthe loss of faith in leadership itself.What I found most striking here (and which I strongly feel is the film‚Äôs strongest aspect) is how Tarog, through Joven‚Äôs eyes, frames Quezon as the unwitting architect of a system that still defines us. Joven suggests that while Quezon didn‚Äôt invent patronage politics, he definitely perfected its choreography: every favor disguised as friendship, every handshake turned into hierarchy. The film doesn‚Äôt condemn him outright for this; it simply watches how such pragmatism metastasizes into a national reflex that still nags at us today.In one exchange, Quezon insists that principle must bend to survival, a line that feels less like justification than prophecy. Tarog lets that sentiment resonate across the film like a curse. We see it in the way Quezon rewards loyalty with access, in the quiet humiliation of those who refuse to play along, and in the hollow triumph of independence negotiated rather than fought for. The movie‚Äôs politics are cyclical, almost fatalistic: power breeds corruption, corruption demands compromise, and compromise becomes governance. Tarog doesn‚Äôt spell this out; he lets it unfold in the pauses between alliances and betrayals, in the small intimate silences that follow Quezon‚Äôs public victories.Joven‚Äôs arc, meanwhile, becomes our moral compass‚Äîa journalist who believes truth can coexist with patronage, only to learn that one always consumes the other. His disillusionment is as national as it is personal. By the time he returns the coin Quezon once gave him, the gesture feels both intimate and historical, like a nation finally returning the debt of false ideals. Tarog‚Äôs ‚ÄúBayaniverse‚Äù has always traced this erosion, but here it feels complete: Quezon may have built the country‚Äôs first Republic, but he also built the template for its recurring undoing.What the film ultimately suggests is that corruption in the Philippines isn‚Äôt an aberration‚Äîit‚Äôs an inheritance. Quezon‚Äôs genius wasn‚Äôt that he corrupted the system, but that he understood how to make corruption look like leadership. His brand of ‚Äúopportunistic nationalism,‚Äù as historians have called it, didn‚Äôt die with him; it evolved, refined by each successor who learned the same survivalist grace. Tarog‚Äôs gaze isn‚Äôt accusatory, though. It‚Äôs almost elegiac, as if recognizing that Quezon‚Äôs contradictions‚Äîhis brilliance, his vanity, his compromises‚Äîare also ours.

As the final chapter of Jerrold Tarog‚Äôs Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon wraps things up in a way that‚Äôs both bold and refreshing. I went into this with zero expectations since it didn‚Äôt get much buzz, but honestly, it‚Äôs a must-watch even if you haven‚Äôt seen Heneral Luna or Goyo. It may not be as explosive or emotionally charged as Heneral Luna, nor as poetic as Goyo, but its quirky, satirical tone gives it a distinct identity that stands strong alongside the first two films.Seeing Quezon‚Äôs story unfold beyond the pages of history books is fascinating. Tarog leans into dark humor and sharp political satire, exposing the manipulative, chaotic world of power struggles ‚Äî Quezon versus fellow politicians and the Americans. This isn‚Äôt your typical biopic; it‚Äôs a political farce where Jericho Rosales‚Äô Quezon treats nationhood like a rigged game only he can win. He lies when needed, bends the truth to his advantage, and embodies both heroism and hypocrisy.What makes this film stand out is its honesty. It doesn‚Äôt glorify Quezon... it exposes his flaws, ambition, and contradictions. The inclusion of media‚Äôs role in shaping narratives adds another layer, reminding us that there are always two sides to every story. The line ‚Äúheroism is just a perception‚Äù sums it up perfectly.Jericho Rosales is phenomenal here that you forget you‚Äôre watching him, he is Quezon. Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, and the actors portraying Osme√±a and Roxas, all deliver sharp, grounded performances that complement the film‚Äôs tone.The ending hits hard with its satirical bite, when Quezon declares, ‚ÄúI am the Philippines.‚Äù Tarog leaves it open to interpretation, but to me, it‚Äôs a powerful commentary on power, ego, and politics ‚Äî on how even noble intentions can rot when corrupted by greed. A hero proclaiming that he is the country becomes the same figure consumed by its flaws. It‚Äôs ironic, timely, and uncomfortably reflective of the state of our nation today.Quezon isn‚Äôt just a political film ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mirror held up to our nation, to our leaders, and to ourselves. It‚Äôs raw, funny, unsettling, and deeply Filipino. A brilliant, unflinching finale to Tarog‚Äôs Bayaniverse.

"madaming pulitiko pero kakaunti lamang ang lingkod-bayan"the last installment to the bayaniverse of tba studios takes a 180 turn in terms of offering its narrative to a hero that this movie is supposed to glorify. While Manuel Quezon remains as a polarizing figure in Philippine history what Quezon offers is trying to show both sides of the coin. That Manuel Quezon has his fair share of contribution to the independence of the country while also not turning a blind eye to his ill deeds. While the film is historically accurate and strong with its references to past events what drags it down is the fictional dramatization for story build-up purposes. My personal fave in this movie hihi that I loved how they told the narrative of the movie within a movie itself (this may make or break the viewing experience depends on the audience preference however in my case it worked!). What confused me, though, was how the film tried to paint Emilio Aguinaldo as a noble hero despite the long-standing accusations against him. Still, as a self-proclaimed history nerd, this film was a feast for my brain and how it challenged, debunked, and reanalyzed so much of what I thought I knew. The sharp dialogues also double as timely social commentary that still hits hard today.

A bit better than Heneral Luna and ties together all the themes established from the first two movies. Siyempre andiyan pa rin yung mga "audience surrogate" scenes in which the characters engage in dialogue that's artificial instead of letting the audience figure it out for themselves. Case in point: yung kumakain sina Joven, Rusca, Carmen at Nadia while mansplaining that being educated doesn't mean you cannot be fooled. Also, I don't understand getting miffed by Quezon's portrayal in a negative light ‚Äî deconstruction is the whole shtick of the "Bayaniverse". It's intended to serve as counterpoints to the textbooks that mythologize historical figures. Hindi naman siya malicious. They're humans after all and politics is intrinsically dirty and ugly. Quezon even correctly points out that Joven is a hypocrite for trying to cast stones. May false equivalence pa yung relative na under Trump daw tayo if Quezon didn't push for independence. Ah ewan. Basta gumana yung tradecraft nila na yan to get more butts in the seats. And on that note, I look forward to phase two with Magsaysay. If there's a Filipino "icon" that's most deserving of the Bayaniverse treatment, it's this guy. Second si Miriam, but Jerrold would probably be super old or (knocks on wood) dead by the time they get to that list.

Aside from pacing issues and a few tonally distracting melodramatic beats, I thought Quezon was a remarkable Philippine production that dared to confront the contradictions behind one of the country‚Äôs most celebrated leaders. "Quezon" is a historical epic and political tragedy about idealism corrupted by power and how the dream of nationhood becomes tangled in propaganda and ego.I think it is essential viewing for anyone interested in Philippine history.

Easily one of my most favorite films of all time, not because of my personal bias towards the Bayaniverse films nor because of my views and opinions on MLQ, but because of how much impact this could make in shaping conversations about our "heroes."Historical figures are all subject to the judgment of history. We cannot confine MLQ into being an exclusively great statesman, nor into a cunning chameleon of a politician. We've got to see the good, the bad, and the ugly.After all, his decisions are a product of the conditions of the Philippines during his time. Love him or hate him, MLQ made his mark in our history. Marks that should be studied and learned from, lest we repeat the mistakes of the past.Anyway, what really stood up to me in this film is the wide use of juxtaposition and contrast in its storytelling, in the conversations between Quezon and Osme√±a, Quezon and Aguinaldo, Aguinaldo and Wood, Wood and Quezon, so on.This film made me want to re-read Nick Joaquin's 'A Question Of Heroes'. And of course, learn more about the man himself, Manuel Luis Quezon. Ironic lang na nauna ko pa ito mapanood before 'Quezon's Game'.Though it must be said. The "government run by hell by Filipinos" is pretty much Quezon's legacy, a legacy of ambition-driven politics fueled by patronage. The film kinda highlighted it splendidly.Pretty much a great film to watch. Informative? Yes. Devil's Advocate? Absolutely!

I finally watched Quezon with my family after we got the time to see it in the cinema. It is the final and third film released after Goyo which was shown seven years ago. This film took several years into production which made me think if ever this will be finished since it would take a lot of money to make it and possibly got delayed because of the pandemic as well.When the cast and more details were announced, I am glad that it still pushed through despite some delays in production. However, what raised some eyebrows is the announcement of Jericho Rosales as Manuel L. Quezon since there was another actor that was supposed to portray an older version of him. I was surprised because Quezon is a mestizo while Rosales is a moreno actor. While I think this must be a miscast, I was intrigued whether he can pull this off since he is also a good actor too and has played lead roles in the past. Watched the movie, I was impressed by Rosales's portrayal of Quezon as an ambitious yet charismatic senator who wants to liberate the Philippines from the Americans. I had my doubts at first that Jerrold Tarog would make Quezon a good person yet what he did in this film he made him a morally grey character. It based Quezon on several historical documents and articles. While it didn't cover much about everything, it is clear that Quezon is what we call in a politics a " trapo" where he uses people to his advantage and perception in winning the elections and attaining power. Watching the film made me realize that everything is still relevant to what is happening today. Same people but different faces. The movie depicts how politics is game for the politicians where the masses are still considered pawns and the rich and elite still dictate everything and control the society. In this film, I didn't root for either Quezon or Aguinaldo. There is neither black and white nor good and bad. Overall, the film is great and entertaining to watch. The veteran and rising cast is great. I also think that Quezon and Osme√±a here have chemistry as rivals turned to running mates. It's also an eye-opener to everyone especially when some of the issues in this film are still relevant to our country. Joven and his family represent our struggle in facing the reality of our country. Corruption is a systemic problem in our country and the film makes us think whether we are truly free. Even if we are independent, imperialism still exists in our country especially with how first world countries interfere with our affairs and also control our economy in other ways. The political system is still same but worse and I can still see Quezon in some politicians in the news. With Quezon showing in cinemas, I hope that more people will learn to discern and choose leaders carefully and see them in a lens where they don't vote them just because they're popular or owe them everything. Quezon is not perfect in terms of production and pacing, but it's a fun watch and has served its purpose for the general public. I'm optimistic that if more people will watch this type of films we might get more genres like them in the future.PS: Stay for the mid-credit scenes.

Whether in a historical drama or in reality, it always pains me to keep seeing, over and over again, how people in power always fail to serve the country they swore to offer their lives for. It‚Äôs always about f* politics (getting in power) and never about the Filipino people.We are the Philippines‚Äîeach and every one of us.Nakakapagod. Ngunit kapag mahal mo ang isang tao, o bagay, kahit ang bansa, gagawin mo ang lahat para dito. Walang sinasarili. Walang kapangyarihang ginagamit para sa sariling pakinabang.Minsang nga‚Äôy tayo pa ang nagbubulag-bulagan sa mga bagay na matagal nang nakikita ng iba. Nakakalungkot na tayo pa ang naghihilahan pababa sa bawa‚Äôt isa para lamang iangat ang ating sarili. Hindi bale na kung maaapektuhan ang iba, ang mahalaga ay tayo‚Äôy nasa tuktok at namumuhay ng ‚Äòmapayapa‚Äô. Sabi nila nakakain daw ang indepensiya kaya‚Äôt ito ay inaasam-asam. Oo, marami ang gutom. Gutom sa mabuting pamumuno at maayos na pamamalakad sa inang bayan.Oh, how we cry for the lives of Filipinos who yearn not just for good governance, but for a life worthy of the freedom we keep celebrating.Tayo ba ay tunay na malaya na? Ano na nga ba ang indepensiya?

jericho delivered a layered performance so i‚Äôll deliver a layered reviewat first, I thought the choice to tell the story from That POV was just a gimmicky choice, like form over substance, but as the film continued it felt like a very relevant meta commentary (idk for sure if that‚Äôs the intention). (For added context for the succeeding parts of this review, Quezon‚Äôs grandson crashed out during a press tour as he claims there are gross inaccuracies in the film.)The way this film dealt about propaganda stuck with me. Choosing to tell the story in that POV further drives the point for me. Quezon‚Äôs grandson crashed out because of inaccuracies, but this film isn‚Äôt supposed to be seen as an historical account (as well as the previous films in this trilogy for that matter). Telling the story from the perspective of the film reels for me feels like the director‚Äôs way of telling us that these films shouldn‚Äôt be read as historical accounts because they are just not. In fact it could even be interpreted as propaganda by some. But that is what the film means to me at least. When TJ Trinidad was recast, I was hesitant, mainly because TJ looked like a modern Manuel Quezon. But after seeing Jericho‚Äôs performance as the titular character, no one could‚Äôve done a better job. The voice, the mannerisms, the small details, it‚Äôs so layered and I could watch it for hours on end. Everyone else in the cast did a fantastic job as well. (Fuck the CongTV cameo tho)I was shocked by how much they grounded Manuel Quezon back to reality and deconstructed the person. Quezon is one of my favorite presidents, but this made me look at him at a less fanatic perspective. Quezon was one smart mf, but that was also his flaw. He may be the our country‚Äôs best example of what a Machiavellian is. He played the cards he was dealt with yes, but he did so knowing the game was rigged while still benefiting from it, and even contributing to the rot. The way imperialism and independence is dealt with here has me conflicted, I still have no cohesive thoughts about how they discussed it, maybe on a rewatch. Politics is a game to those in power even if it shouldn‚Äôt be because our lives depend on it. ALSO the tension built in the Bagac Bataan scene IS SO!!!!!!also i geeked tf out when they mentioned Murnau like hellooo (felt like the director just wanna flex his knowledge about filmmaking but still appreciated lol)anyways, I need to see it again

Nagkaroon kami ng isang diskurso pauwi pagkatapos naming panoorin ang Quezon. Matapos ko pa lang masaksihan ang pelikulang ito ay batid ko na ang ipinapahiwatig nito, hindi kailanman magiging malinis ang pulitika sapagkat ito ay laro lamang sa mata ng mga namumuno. Ang manipulasyon ni MLQ ay tila masasabi kong napakagaling, hindi kapuri-puri ngunit nakakamanghang bawat hadlang na kanyang haharapin ay mayroong plano kahit na hindi pa ito magtagumpay.Isa lamang ang konklusyon na makukuha rito, mula noon hanggang ngayon, mula kay Aguinaldo, Quezon, Duterte, at Marcos ay walang pinagbago ang namumuno sa ating bansa. Kaya naman, bumoto ng tama at bumoses para sa mamamayang Pilipino!P.S. We saw Mr. Mon Confiado and Benjamin Alves in the flesh and they even gave a small talk! Thank you direk for this film :)
